bug.short_desc: Errata in EpsilonBook.pdf, 29-Nov-2010 (mostly typos)

long_desc.thetext:
24, Figure 3.1: personally, I find EBNF much easier to read than class diagrams. (Not an erratum.)
p 25. It is not immediately clear that the context-type of an operation is specified after the keyword operation and the return type is specified after the final colon (Listing 3.1 uses Integer for both the context and the return type).
The self special variable should be explained.
p 25., 2nd para: s/Therefore, in line 3/Therefore, in line 1/
p 27., Listing 3.4 I find this ambiguous: do the parenthesis belong to the concrete sytax or do they group the regular expression? @ should be bold to clarify that this is a terminal symbol (as should $ in Listing 3.5).
p 38. after definition of "excluding(item : Any)": s/hline/\\hline/
p 39. s/Also, EOL collection support/Also, EOL collections support/
p 60., Table 3.15, chooseMany s/to select one/to select one or more/
p 78, Listing 4.8 I could not find a definition of the typeOf keyword.
p 96. s/In line 4/In line 5/
p 144. s/displayed in Figurer/displayed in Figure/
p 147. s/The Nodes merge rule In line/The \\emph{MergeNodes} rule in line/
p 152. s/explicit variables (matching CT, matchingAT/explicit variables (matchingCT, matchingAC/

The syntax for collection literals (e.g., Sequence { 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 } isn't formally defined.
The syntax for other literals (e.g. strings, including escape sequences, etc.) isn't defined either.
The form of comments aren't defined.gT
Many thanks for pointing out these issues.
p 74,, 3rd para: s/ivnariants/invariants/
The EVL chapter does not show the concrete syntax of pre and post blocks. If the syntax is the same as in ETL, you could reference Listing 5.2.
Listing 4.4, 4.5, 4.6: Braces, colons, and at signs need to be emboldened, since they are part of the concrete syntax.
The concrete syntax of critique levels is not shown.

(In reply to comment #5) > Listing 4.4, 4.5, 4.6: Braces, colons, and at signs need to be emboldened, > since they are part of the concrete syntax.
You are probably using a listing package that emboldens keywords. Perhaps you could mark up "templates" (akin to EBNF productions) differently, to make the distinction between terminals and non-terminal clear.

(In reply to comment #5) > Listing 4.4, 4.5, 4.6: Braces, colons, and at signs need to be emboldened, > since they are part of the concrete syntax.
You are probably using a listing package that emboldens keywords. Perhaps you could mark up "templates" (akin to EBNF productions) differently, to make the distinction between terminals and non-terminal clear.

Listing 4.4 omits guards from contexts. Listing 4.6 falsely allows guards in fixes.
However, I find guarded fixes useful: a fix might not always be applicable.
Real numbers do not support exponents. This should be documented or fixed in the implementation.

I have resolved most of the minor issues which didn't affect the implementation. There are still a few things to do, though:
- I'm afraid that using an EBNF for the EOL abstract syntax may confuse readers into thinking that is the actual concrete syntax.
- I have looked at the code and I didn't find the actual typeOf keyword. Do we really support it?
- We still need to write the section on literals, but I'd like to integrate the patch in #340669 before doing that.
- I still need to check if the syntax for pre/post blocks is the same for ETL and EVL. I think they are the same, as I believe it is defined in a common ancestor, ERL.
- I also have to inspect the code handling the EVL critique levels to write that part.
- We have a bug for fix guards: #286148
- I'll have a look at the real number handling code.

I have improved EOL's support for real literals, as shown in bug #346641: https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=346641
I will shortly add a section on literals to the Epsilon book.
I have added a section to the EOL book on literals. I'll work a bit more on the other issues during the next week.

Conferences and other things got the better of me. I've looked at some of the pending issues:
(In reply to comment #11) > - I have looked at the code and I didn't find the actual typeOf keyword. Do we > really support it?
I still can't find any reference to typeOf except in the EvlEditor class, which highlights it as a keyword. Should we simply remove this keyword from the editor and the documentation?
> - I still need to check if the syntax for pre/post blocks is the same for ETL > and EVL. I think they are the same, as I believe it is defined in a common > ancestor, ERL.
They are the same. I have copied the pre/post concrete syntax from ETL over to EML and ECL.
> - I also have to inspect the code handling the EVL critique levels to write > that part.
Just like typeOf, it is mentioned in the book, but it is not implemented. Is it worth implementing? Should I remove it from the documentation?
> - We have a bug for fix guards: #286148
I'll work on it a bit now, seeing as we have a recent comment on it (August 23rd).
I have implemented fix guards in EVL, so there's only typeOf and the critique levels left. Should we implement them, or should we remove them from the Epsilon book?
I'm happy with removing them from the book (limiting the range of types can always be done in the guard)
I've removed all mentions of typeOf and critique levels in the book. I think we can close this bug now.
Fixed in 1.0

bug.short_desc: Ref attributes propositions are missing when editing a model (Exeed)

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 234395 project to reproduce the bug
--> To reproduce the bug: - Register metamodels in "/metamodels" - Open file "tests/target/distribution.model" - Select any Commodity element. Its "quality" property shoudl display a valid reference (to another element in the same file) - Click on the quality property value to change it, it disappears and the dropdown list is empty.
The expected behaviour would be to have a list of all commodity quality instances...
Created attachment 234397 Traces of the eclipse application (exceptions run from epsilon)

--> More details - If I try to run an eclipse application including my project as a plugin, then I can edit the model properly. I still get some usefull exceptions inside Epsilon (see traces.txt attached). - I tried to create the XMI file from within the editor and reached the same problem, so it's not a problem with the Epsilon transformation. - The model has instances from 2 metamodels (one of which references the other). I don't know if it has consequences.
--> My guesses - The fact that the editor works (with exceptions though) from an eclipse app suggests a problem with Epsilon EPackage registry. Indeed, when run as an eclipse app, I guess the metamodels get registered directly in the EMF metamodel - Could be related to bug #325010 - Could be related to bug #414675
Please note this has been tested on WINDOWS XP only, with eclipse 3.6, 4.2 and 4.3.

I have been fishing around the code for a bit and the code that lists the items in the combo box is not even part of Exeed, but of EMF. It's this method:
org.eclipse.emf.edit.provider.ItemPropertyDescriptor#getComboBoxObjects
From what I see, it appears as if the CommodityQuality EClass was being instantiated twice: when listing elements for the combo box, it tries to find all instances of the first copy of the CommodityQuality EClass and it only finds instances of the *second* copy of the CommodityQuality EClass, so it shows an empty list.
I'll keep looking at this tomorrow: I'm not sure why these two instances are being created.

Ah, it ended up being much simpler than I thought. You have a problem in your mmOUT2.emf file. In particular, you have this:
import "platform:/resource/forum.tests/metamodels/mmTarget1.ecore";
It should be this:
import "http://org.epsilon.tests/target/1/1.0.0";
Try it:
1. Remove the mmOUT1 and mmOUT2 entries from your EMF Registry (look for the "EMF Registry" section in your Prferences).
2. Register your mmTarget1.ecore file.
3. Fix the import statement in your mmTarget2.emf file and regenerate the .ecore file from it.
4. Register your mmTarget2.ecore file.
5. Load the distribution.model file. It should now work just fine.
You see, there is a *big* difference between those two import statements.
With a file-based import:
1. Register mmTarget1.ecore file -> instance A of the mmOUT1 EPackage is created.
2. Register mmTarget2.ecore file -> in addition to the mmOUT2 EPackage is created, a new instance B of the mmOUT1 EPackage is *also* created, as Eclipse will blindly follow the file-based reference.
3. Therefore, within a CommodityQualityContainer we have A.Commodity objects, and within a Distributor we have B.Commodity objects. Since they are different EClass instances, you get the empty combo boxes.
With an URI-based import:
1. Register mmTarget1.ecore file -> an instance of the mmOUT1 EPackage is created.
2. Register mmTarget2.ecore file -> the mmOUT2 EPackage is created and the previously registered instance of mmOUT1 is reused.
3. We use the same instance of the Commodity EClass everywhere, and we have no problems.
Closing this as not a bug. For future users who run into this: if you need to refer to another metamodel from an .emf file, please use URI-based imports instead of file-based imports :-).
Just pushed out a new interim release which should include the fix for this issue.

Traces of the eclipse application (exceptions run from epsilon)

bug.short_desc: Preserve files that are not modified

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 221724 Patch to implement this feature
See http://www.eclipse.org/forums/index.php/m/929389/#msg_929389
Basically, EGL should not write files that did not change. This is convenient for large models/proejcts with lots of files that does not need to get recompiled.

Created attachment 221725 Missing dependency fix
I also found a missing dependency (at least for me)
Created attachment 221735 Updated patch to cover cases where protectRegions==false

Louis: Could you perhaps review this patch when you get a chance?
On a side-note I've had a look at FileUtil.read and it appears to be reading the provided file character by character. It seems like it's doing this so that it can properly manage new line characters but I suspect there could be a more efficient way to do this. Any thoughts on this?

Good catch, I totally forgot about situations where no protected regions were present...
About the reading method: using some readLine() method and defining a standard EOL char should work as well. If critical, this EOL char could be configurable.
In http://stackoverflow.com/questions/326390/how-to-create-a-java-string-from-the-contents-of-a-file they seem to read the complete file into a buffer at once. But I am not sure how much of a 'hack' such a method is.

Thanks for the suggestion and patch!
I'll take a look at integrating this soon; we'll need regression tests to cover this new behaviour.

I've fixed this now, and added a couple of regression tests.
I went a slightly different route in the end, as doGenerate was getting a bit long and had quite a bit of conceptual duplication. The final version is here: https://dev.eclipse.org/svnroot/modeling/org.eclipse.epsilon/trunk/plugins/org.eclipse.epsilon.egl.engine/src/org/eclipse/epsilon/egl/EglFileGeneratingTemplate.java
As for the FileUtil.read method, annoyingly readLine() won't work for all of our use cases, as it does not distinguish between files that have or do not have a trailing linebreak. Given how sensitive some programs can be to the absence or presence of trailing linebreaks (e.g. Promla/SPIN; Eclipse's manifest files), EGL respects the presence/absence of trailing line breaks in existing files. After a quick Google, I can't see a sane way to use readLine() and pass all of FileUtil.read's test cases. Do let me know if you have any neat tricks though; I know relatively few of those when it comes to Java IO! :D
Marking as fixed in SVN for now. Feel free to re-open if you'd like to revisit the FileUtil.read issue though, chaps.
Fixed in 1.0

attachment.desc: Patch to implement this feature
Missing dependency fix
Updated patch to cover cases where protectRegions==false

bug.short_desc: Add @multiple anontation to allow rule to execute multiple times

long_desc.thetext:
There is a "de facto" standard in transformation languages (a least the ones I have used) in which a rule is executed one per element. I guess the engine keeps track of element xmi:id and prevents the rule form being executed more than once for a given element. I have stumble a case in which I need a rule to be executed two or more times for the same element and create different (new) output elements each time.
I propose to add the @multiple annotation which would tell the engine to re execute the rule even of the xmi:id has been processed before. To avoid infinite loops this annotation can only be added to lazy rules.
I suspect that for such cases an operation may be preferable to a rule. Would this perhaps work in your case?

Well... the operation is one solution, been using this approach for some of my transformation, but the down side of this is that you loose the trace. The other thing I tried was the solution I commented on my post (http://www.eclipse.org/forums/index.php/t/351384/ ), but as stated there this approach is a bit of a hassle, but I am hoping (not tested yet) that extended properties are stred in the trace too.
At the end I think what matters is the trace, at least imho. So that is why y propose the annotation.
OK. Makes sense.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of bug 329328 ***

bug.short_desc: ETL transformation rule execution time increases

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 230900 Transformation and model example, including metamodel
When using the attached ETL rules on a large model, the running time of a single rule increases from 8ms to 45ms. This indicates that there is either some implicit linear behavior in the rules, or that the equivalent() call is the bottleneck.
BTW: I am aware of the special assignment operator (i.e. ::= ) but for clarity, chose to write out the 'equivalent()' explicitly.
Reproduce, generate model by using a default genmodel, then run the attached ETL on the attached model.
If there are any other potential performance bottlenecks that I did not take into account, I would be happy to hear about them!
Thanks! The transformation doesn't seem to have made it in the zip file; could you please attach it separately?

Created attachment 230902 Missing transformation file
Ah, I see I accidentally zipped the launch file iso the ETL file...
It's a very trivial 'migration'/'copy' transformation, and does not contain any of the logic that the original transformation contained.
Thanks. I'll try to have a look at this as soon as possible.

Did you get a chance to investigate this? The HashMap that is used to keep the mapping from target to source could become larger when so many entries are used. However, because it is a HashMap, this should not influence the performance (at least not in this order of magnitude).

I've had a look at this and the delay is due to the heavy use of @lazy rules. Removing the @lazy annotations reduces execution time from ~106 sec to ~6 sec on my machine. Lazy rules are indeed slower as every time the engine tries to execute x.equivalent() it has to find a suitable rule that can transform x - which is expensive.
I've also added a note about this to the book.

(In reply to comment #5) > I've had a look at this and the delay is due to the heavy use of @lazy > rules. Removing the @lazy annotations reduces execution time from ~106 sec > to ~6 sec on my machine. Lazy rules are indeed slower as every time the > engine tries to execute x.equivalent() it has to find a suitable rule that > can transform x - which is expensive.
Ah, I see! That's unfortunate, as most of the elements in these models are expressions, and testing if they should be transformed is a costly bottom-up + top-down procedure. Therefore, I needed more control in the execution mechanism (ergo the .equivalent calls and lazy rules), such that only the expressions that actually need to be transformed are considered in the ETL rules. The model files I am using may contain parts that are not relevant for this call of the model transformation.
(In reply to comment #6) > I've also added a note about this to the book.
Cheers!

(In reply to comment #7) > (In reply to comment #5) > > I've had a look at this and the delay is due to the heavy use of @lazy > > rules. Removing the @lazy annotations reduces execution time from ~106 sec > > to ~6 sec on my machine. Lazy rules are indeed slower as every time the > > engine tries to execute x.equivalent() it has to find a suitable rule that > > can transform x - which is expensive. > > Ah, I see! That's unfortunate, as most of the elements in these models are > expressions, and testing if they should be transformed is a costly bottom-up > + top-down procedure. Therefore, I needed more control in the execution > mechanism (ergo the .equivalent calls and lazy rules), such that only the > expressions that actually need to be transformed are considered in the ETL > rules. The model files I am using may contain parts that are not relevant > for this call of the model transformation. > > (In reply to comment #6) > > I've also added a note about this to the book. > > Cheers!
Come to think of it, I may be able to solve that by caching the result (whether or not to be transformed) per Expression. But even then, it can become a performance problem if the user defines multiple (unconnected) large model parts... Have to think about (and experiment with) this a bit more, to see if this is a bad design on my side.
This makes sense as a temporary workaround. We're currently working on static analysis of Epsilon programs so we'll hopefully be able to improve performance of lazy rules in the future.

long_desc.thetext:
Steps to Reproduce: follow this tutorial http://www.eclipse.org/gmt/epsilon/doc/articles/evl-gmf-inte gration/ with slight changes:
Step 3 - I'm using an EVL constraint which is compatible for the UML meta-model:
context Class { critique constraint1 { check { 'checked'.println(); return not(self.name = 'Foo'); } message: "problem with class" fix { title: "DummyFix" do {} } } }
and added its path to the binary build tab.
Step 4 - I've added the org.eclipse.epsilon.evl.emf.validation extension and created a new constraint binding in it with the following details:

class: org.eclipse.epsilon.evl.emf.validation.EvlMarkerResolutionGe nerator markerType: org.eclipse.emf.ecore.diagnostic

bug.short_desc: links created with EWL do no appear in diagram

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 171673 while the model itself is pretty complicated, it provides wizards for all mentioned cases. for testing link references, use the 'create repository' wizard
Overview: When creating links in the base object of a diagram, all links appear as they should be, both link references and link classes. When creating links inside another container (like a package class or other container), no links appear (neither references nor classes). When creating links that cross a container boundary (such as the above mentioned package), link references appear immediately, while link classes do not.
Steps to Reproduce:
1. create a metamodel containing regular classes, reference links, link classes and container classes 2. create a wizard that transforms one type of node class into another, and sets all link classes and link references that pointed to the old node to point to the new node. allow the user to choose which container to place the new object into. 3. place node objects in a container class, and others outside (in the root container). create links among the nodes 4. transform objects using the wizard that are inside the container; place the new objects both inside and outside the container
Actual Results: When creating links inside another container, no links appear. When creating links that cross a container boundary, link references appear immediately, while link classes do not.
Expected Results: All links should appear immediately in the diagram.
EWL only interacts with the underlying EMF resource and it's then the responsibility of the GMF editor to update the graphical view accordingly. Closing as invalid.
Closed as invalid.

bug.short_desc: Epsilon book fixes

long_desc.thetext: Long listings in the EVL chapter overflow instead of breaking to the next page (I've verified that this hasn't always been the case). The borders of the book are also too wide and need to be reduced for the benefit of trees.

Additionally to some typos, completing information (for example the ones in http://www.eclipse.org/forums/index.php/t/313559/ and http://www.eclipse.org/forums/index.php/t/292497/) and fixing some references to the source code and examples that have mistakes. Probably some more examples will help understand some of the more complex parts.
I see from the repository that the book is written in latex. I have some experience with it and was wondering if it is possible to give you a hand with this how can I help.
That'd be great indeed! Please feel free to implement these changes and submit a patch so that we can then apply them to the SVN trunk.

On a quick update on this I started by working on the margins. I have sucesfully changed the margins so that the printed area is bigger and that the text starts at the top margin (currently a space was always left).
My plan is to work on he listings and on some italic and tt texts that get printed outside the marging. After done with the visual aspects I will try to gather info from the forums and bugs to see what needs to be change and change it.

On a quick update on this I started by working on the margins. I have sucesfully changed the margins so that the printed area is bigger and that the text starts at the top margin (currently a space was always left).
My plan is to work on he listings and on some italic and tt texts that get printed outside the marging. After done with the visual aspects I will try to gather info from the forums and bugs to see what needs to be change and change it.

Ok. Regarding listings it turned out that the float option was defined for all of them. This works with small ones, but larger ones should not use the float option so they can expand several pages. So it a bit of a hassle but each individual listing should use the float option depending on how it fits best on that particular part of the text. I have attached a pdf of how it is looking so far. Some listings still need tweaking (for example why, most of them, have a blank line 1) and added floats appropriately. There is a strange behavior with table of contents and figure lists and they are in some pages single spaced and in others double spaced... which is weird. Also, I added a lstlisting list but it is not generated.
Nest step would be to add aforementioned additions and corrections.
Created attachment 217645 Epsilon book pdf
Thanks for your hard work on this! Could you perhaps attach a patch with the changes you've made so far?

I was going to attach a zip of the book tex sources with my changes, but don't know if this is the correct way to submit a patch and it seems if I choose patch files an be larger than 2000k . Please advice on the best way to submit the changes, maybe only the tex files? I think there has been a change or to to the book (from what I've read on the forums) so a merge would be probably required.

Please try to update your local copy, resolve any conflicts and then export the patch file that captures only the changes made to .tex files. In Subclipse this can be done by right-clicking on the project and then selecting Team-Create Patch.

Updated ad resolved conflicts. Please tell me if this is what you needed.

Created attachment 219336 Tables fit new margins
Since the margins are wider I changed some of the tables in the EOL chapter to make use of the additional space. Since my copy did not change after an update I have marked the past patch obsolete.

UserInput.prompt* methods are now refactored to System.user.prompt* methods. The book does not reflect this. (Pure EOL modules will throw a warning and redirect the method, but e.g. ETL modules throw an exception for an unknown type UserInput)

Could you perhaps "rebase" your modifications on the latest version of these files and submit an updated patch for these 2 files? Sorry about that; if it's too much work I'll try to do this when time permits.

Created attachment 224741 Formatting
I have done a new formatting revision to the latest version. I have changed the Titlepage so that all the authors are referenced and it is more practical (instead of having to change the png). In the future we could possibly change the colors and font so that it looks more like the original png.
Listings where moved around a bit so they are closer to the explanation (mostly in the EOL chapater). Tables where modified to use the new margins (excepts the ones for the operators which looked funny with cells so big). Some lines where changed to actually be a single line instead of consecutive multiple single lines .
I believe I applied these fixes when they were submitted but forgot to update the status of the bug. Please feel free to reopen if I've missed anything.
Closing as fixed.

Tables fit new margins
Formatting

bug.short_desc: Checks for EVL quick fixes aren't run in read-only mode from the EMF editor's "Validate" menu entry

long_desc.thetext:
Thanks for reporting this. The EMF/EVL integration only contributes validators to the EMF validation framework (and GMF picks them up) so in fact EVL is not aware of the environment in which it is executed... I'll need to look into this more closely and perhaps escalate with the EMF/GMF developers.
Is this a blocker or just a nuisance?
It's only a nuisance. I'll use the validation from the GMF editor for the time being.
This bug has been around for a while and I don't see how we could remedy this given that EVL - like all languages in Epsilon - does not support a "read-only" mode. Closing as "won't fix".
Closing as wontfix.

attachment.desc: Set of projects which reproduce the issue

bug.short_desc: EOL Annotations failing silently

long_desc.thetext:
Hi,
Ran into a issue with a slow running EOL program. Problem was found to be using @cache instead of @cached after extensive debugging.
Richard said to pass it along.

I can't see how we could improve this as annotations may be consumed by arbitrary clients (e.g. a hypothetical user-contributed Java tool may actually make use of @cache annotations). I'm afraid we'll have to close this as won't fix.
Closed as won't fix

bug.short_desc: Non-Synchronized GMF validation model marker inconsistency

long_desc.thetext: If you use validation from a model that is not synchronized, the markers do not show up correctly. If you validate from a diagram, you see errors for all entities in the model even if they are not on the diagram. The resource is the diagram though, so when you click on it it cannot find it to navigate to.
Apologies for not being particularly responsive on this. I'll look into this next week when I'm back to work.

EVL is invoked through the EMF validation framework which only provides access to the EMF resource underpinning the diagram so unfortunately, EVL cannot know whether a particular element appears on the diagram or not.

bug.short_desc: epsilon.loadModel readOnLoad failure

long_desc.thetext:
If epsilon.loadModel attribute 'readOnLoad' is set to 'true' and there is no model to read the task fails (crashes). The task should create (but not store unless directed to do so) an empty model in memory and continue processing.
Bug demonstrable with Epsilon 0.8.9.
Example task: <epsilon.loadModel name="${MessageSet}" type="EMF"> <parameter name="expand" value="true"/> <parameter name="modelFile" file="${TargetFile}"/> <parameter name="metamodelUri" value="${TargetMessageSetUri}"/> <parameter name="readOnLoad" value="true"/> <parameter name="storeOnDisposal" value="true"/> </epsilon.loadModel>
A problem with the proposed solution is that then any wrong/mistyped filenames would be silently accepted. As such, I'd be inclined to keep the existing behaviour.
Closing as invalid.

bug.short_desc: Epsilon ANT build cycles from failure to success

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 167928 Epsilon build: registers 2 metamodels, loads 3 models, runs ECL & EML scripts
When running the attached .xml file as an ANT build the first epsilon.loadModel instruction fails. When run a second time the third epsilon.loadModel fails. Running a third time results in the first load failing again. But! on the fourth time the build claims to succeed.
This pattern repeats over and over. I have also observed it with other Epsilon examples, some having fewer models (it only seems to happen with the readOnLoad models).
In this case, the build claims success on the fourth try, but it actually experiences an error on disposeModels target, reporting that resource /home cannot be found. Also, the Target.model file is not actually changed by the build, though one would expect the merge target to change it.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of bug 386255 ***

bug.short_desc: epsilon.loadModel fails for relative paths

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 219329 Complete console output of problem behaviour
[This bug has similarities to https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=285559 , but is reported separately (as suggested)]
= General Description =
When an ETL transformation is fired from an Ant task, epsilon.loadModel fails when refering to the file by <parameter name="foo" file="model/foo.xmi">, but is successful with <parameter name="foo" value="../fooProject/model/foo.xmi">
= Experienced Behaviour (Problem) =
A model of the Kingdom of Saxony (Saxony.xmi, metamodel kingdom.ecore) is to be transformed to a republic (Republic_of_Saxony.xmi, metamodel republic.ecore) by an ETL transformation.
The transformation is governed by an Ant task (adapted from oo2db_launch.xml supplied with Epsilon´s OO2DB example) which contains the following loadModel entry (existing instance model that is used as input, output model directive is similar and not shown here):
<epsilon.loadModel name="kingdom" type="EMF"> <parameter name="modelFile" file="model/Saxony.xmi"/> <parameter name="metamodelUri" value="kingdom"/> <parameter name="readOnLoad" value="true"/> <parameter name="storeOnDisposal" value="false"/> </epsilon.loadModel>
Running it (Run as -> 1 Ant Build) gives the following console output (see attachment for complete output including stack trace):
Buildfile: /home/fab/workspace-epsilon/revolution_Transformation /revolution_launch.xml
loadModels: [epsilon.loadModel] Internal error: org.eclipse.emf.ecore.resource.Resource$IOWrappedException: Resource '/home /fab/workspace-epsilon/revolution_Transformation/model/Saxony.xmi' does not exist.
The relative path from the launch script is correctly expanded towards the absolute path shown, which is perfectly correct (everything is fine with the file, see next section).
= Experienced Behaviour (Workaround) =
Inspired by the solutions to the similar problem reported in this bug report here (the one I'm jsut adding a comment to), I've figured out that altering the modelFile entries fixes the problem. The following works and produces a correct result:
<parameter name="modelFile" value="../revolution_Transformation/model/Saxony.xmi"/>
But neighter
<parameter name="modelFile" file="../revolution_Transformation/model/Saxony.xmi"/>
nor
<parameter name="modelFile" value="model/Saxony.xmi"/>
= Expected Behaviour =
The workaround should not be needed, (Problem) should work as well as (Workaround).
= Let´s Add Some Confusion =
Let´s get back to the state with the 'wrong' launch script. That´s the ETL script (nothing wrong with that so far):
pre { 'ETL starts'.println(); }
post { 'ETL done'.println(); }
-- simple mapping: each and every creature becomes an equal citizen rule Dragon2Citizen transform d : kingdom!Dragon to c : republic!Citizen { 'dragon2citizen'.println(); c.name := d.name; }
There is one dragon in the source model.
Actually the problem described in the above section only shows up *exactly* every second time I run the Ant script. It takes turns with a *different* problem. Every second time, the program seems to run successfully (even though the launch script is 'wrong'):
Buildfile: /home/fab/workspace-epsilon/revolution_Transformation /revolution_launch.xml
loadModels:
main: [epsilon.etl - revolution.etl] ETL starts [epsilon.etl - revolution.etl] ETL done
BUILD SUCCESSFUL Total time: 309 milliseconds
Please note that dragon2citizen is never called. If the loadModel directive of the output model is 'wrong', no output model (not even an empty one) is generated. If its loadmodel directive is correct (but still not the one of the source model), an empty model is generated.
I don´t have any idea how the turn-taking behaviour comes into play. It is however fixed by using 'correct' loadModel directives for both entries: a correct republic model inhabited by a single citizen is delivered and the following console output is produced *every time it is run* (no strange take-turns here):
main: [epsilon.etl - revolution.etl] ETL starts [epsilon.etl - revolution.etl] dragon2citizen [epsilon.etl - revolution.etl] ETL done
= System Details =
* Epsilon Core 0.9.1.201107251201 * Eclipse Modeling Tools, Indigo Service Release 2, Build id: 20120216-1857 * Linux AMD64, fully updated Ubuntu 10.04.4 LTS
Please let me know whether I can provide you with additional information to investigate the issue or help in other ways! Thank you very much!

I was able to reproduce this with our tree2graph example, which also uses the epsilon.loadTask and modelFile property.
There were 2 issues:
- The intermittent errors were due to the fact that EMF was caching the model that was unsuccessfully loaded as if it were correctly loaded. The next turn, it would fail in a different place, so it would be unloaded. And the turn after that, it'd be wrongly cached again.
This has been fixed in SVN r1920 by unloading the model in case we run into an IOException while loading the model. We can consistently produce the same error again and again now.
- The oddities with "file" and "value" were due to the way the deprecated modelFile parameter was being migrated to the modelUri parameter. The migration code would always try to build a platform:/resource/ URI out of the absolute path that file="model/foo.xmi" was producing, which was wrong.
This has also been fixed in , by first checking in the migration if the path leads to a regular file and not to a workspace resource. If it's not a path to a regular file, we will transform it into a platform:/resource/ URI as usual.
I have also updated the old example so instead of
<parameter name="modelFile" file="x.model" />
it uses
<parameter name="modelUri" file="file://${basedir}/x.model" />
, which is the recommended syntax in the current version of Epsilon.
@fabtagon: since you're loading EMF models, I would suggest that you use the specialized <epsilon.emf.loadModel> task, which is easier to use. For instance:
<epsilon.emf.loadModel name="Kingdom" modelFile="model/kingdom.xmi" metamodelUri="..." read="true" store="false"/>
<epsilon.emf.loadModel name="Republic" modelFile="model/republic.xmi" metamodelUri="..." read="false" store="store"/>
I'd normally only use the general-purpose <epsilon.loadModel> task if I were using any other EMC driver.

Thanks for your clarification and advice, Antonio!
I (or better said grep) took a look into the svn. Additionally the following examples seem to be affected by the same issue:
org.eclipse.epsilon.examples.buildooinstance/launch.xml org.eclipse.epsilon.examples.mddtif/codegeneration/TVApp2Xml.xml org.eclipse.epsilon.examples.mddtif/livereport/MergeReportWithTVApp.xml org.eclipse.epsilon.examples.mddtif/competitions/Competition2TVApp.xml org.eclipse.epsilon.examples.mergeentitywithvocabulary/build.xml org.eclipse.epsilon.examples.mergeoo/MergeOO.xml org.eclipse.epsilon.examples.oo2db/launch.xml org.eclipse.epsilon.examples.oomerging/build.xml

(In reply to comment #2) > Thanks for your clarification and advice, Antonio! > > I (or better said grep) took a look into the svn. Additionally the following > examples seem to be affected by the same issue: > > org.eclipse.epsilon.examples.buildooinstance/launch.xml > org.eclipse.epsilon.examples.mddtif/codegeneration/TVApp2Xml.xml > org.eclipse.epsilon.examples.mddtif/livereport/MergeReportWithTVApp.xml > org.eclipse.epsilon.examples.mddtif/competitions/Competition2TVApp.xml > org.eclipse.epsilon.examples.mergeentitywithvocabulary/build.xml > org.eclipse.epsilon.examples.mergeoo/MergeOO.xml > org.eclipse.epsilon.examples.oo2db/launch.xml > org.eclipse.epsilon.examples.oomerging/build.xml
Hi Fabian,
Thanks! I've replaced epsilon.loadModel for epsilon.emf.loadModel in those files now. I've also added a short paragraph describing epsilon.emf.loadModel to the Epsilon Book's chapter on the orchestration Ant tasks. It was only described in the more recent EUnit chapter until now.
Cheers, Antonio

There is a small regression with the launch script of the tree2graph example ( examples/org.eclipse.epsilon.examples.tree2graph/launch.xml ). The loadmodel entry for tree goes
<epsilon.emf.loadModel name="Tree" type="EMF" modelFile="tree.model" metamodelUri="Tree" read="true" store="false"/>
which results in
BUILD FAILED /home/fab/workspace-emftext/test/launch.xml:24: epsilon.emf.loadModel doesn't support the "type" attribute
Remove the type attribute and everything is just fine. The error is both online and in svn. Have a nice weekend!

(In reply to comment #4) > Remove the type attribute and everything is just fine. The error is both > online and in svn. Have a nice weekend!
Oops, sorry! Thanks for the catch :-).
I've fixed this in SVN. IIRC, we use the same copy for the web version, so that should be fixed as well.
Fixed in 1.0

bug.short_desc: Exception due to opening dialog in non-UI thread

long_desc.thetext:
Hi,
In the Epsilon forum I started a topic on using the progress monitor during EVL base validations: http://www.eclipse.org/forums/index.php/m/987808/
With my patch (bug #395261) it is still not working. I run validation on a background thread (Job) because they tend to take (too) long. When the suer cancels the monitor (or any other exception worthy thing happens) LogUtil#log(String message, Exception ex, boolean openErrorDialog) is called by EVLValidator, with openErrorDialog set to true.
This is fine when the validation is executed from the UI Thread, but in my case it results in another exception: org.eclipse.swt.SWTException: Invalid thread access at org.eclipse.swt.SWT.error(SWT.java:4361) at org.eclipse.swt.SWT.error(SWT.java:4276) at org.eclipse.swt.SWT.error(SWT.java:4247) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.error(Display.java:1157) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.checkDevice(Display.java:749) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.getActiveShell(Display.java:1347) at org.eclipse.epsilon.common.dt.util.LogUtil.log(LogUtil.java:49) at org.eclipse.epsilon.evl.emf.validation.EvlValidator.validate(EvlValidator.java:172) at org.eclipse.epsilon.evl.emf.validation.EvlValidator.validate(EvlValidator.java:101) at org.eclipse.epsilon.evl.emf.validation.CompositeEValidator.validate(CompositeEValidator.java:47) ...from here it is my application...
It happens because of MessageDialog#openError() in the used log() method.
It is easily solvable by not opening the message dialog anymore. But I suppose this is an undesired solution... :) Better would be to rethrow the exception and let the validation invoking application catch it, but it is less user-friendly (well developer-friendly)
So I do not have a patch (yet), since I guess you guys have to decide your the desired course of action is...
Cheers, Maarten

Additionally: Maybe the MessageDialog is not required (or shown optionally) when the user aborted the validation? As the user probably know (s)he canceled the validation...
Note: This does not solve the problem of the log() method for other exceptional cases!

Another easy to implement solution is running the log() method using the Display#asyncExec() method.
Or maybe even add such a solution to the log() method(s) themselves to fix all problematic occurrences?

Thanks. I've fixed this in LogUtil itself. Could you perhaps update and confirm that this fixes the problem for you?
(In reply to comment #2) > Or maybe even add such a solution to the log() method(s) themselves to fix > all problematic occurrences?
*** Bug 386240 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

It looks good to me. I will test it tomorrow, as it takes quite some effort to use modified versions of Epsilon from source code. (Except the org.eclipse.epsilon.evl.em.validation plugin, as I have a direct copy embedded in my application due to the amount of changes in EVLValidator :) )
An additional note: It is not required to put the call to log(String, Exception) method in the asyncExec() runnable. (It does not hurt either, I suppose)
> Additionally: Maybe the MessageDialog is not required (or shown optionally) > when the user aborted the validation? As the user probably know (s)he canceled > the validation...
An implication of using the log() method for canceled validations is, that a dialog is shown and a log message is added for each EVL validator I have... (currently about ten if the first validation is canceled)
Is it possible (according to your design 'rules') to not log the canceled validators at all? If not, or to find a solution to show only one dialog and log message?
Maarten, did you have time to test this, so we can close the bug?
Yes you can close this bug, thanks!
Closing as fixed after confirmation from Maarten :-).

So it > would be interesting to have this automatization too. Although is more > important to have the complete automatization when using the Generate GMF > editor action. > > Thanks.
Hi Silvia,
This bug was fixed shortly after your report, particularly on SVN r1744 (March 2012). Sorry for the delay in the update.

bug.short_desc: [Eugenia] Appear in the editor two gmf.links (instead of one) between two gmf.nodes

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 223460 Emfatic source of the metamodel with the annotating elements
It's possible to generate the editor from the emf annotated source in attachment with no errors, but using the generated diagram editor I have the follow issue.
1) Create an AreaDefinition 2) Inside the AreaDefinition create two Views 3) Try to create a Connector between these two Views
The editor shows two different choices (instead of only one) of the Create Connector context menu: 1) Clicking on the first one the editor draws two different links connector between the two views 2) Clicking on the second one the editor draws nothing and the eclipse console shows an exception
I'm using this distributions: http://www.eclipse.org/epsilon/download/

Created attachment 226918 Changed metamodel without the issue
Hi Mirco,
Sorry for the delay. If you check the .gmfmap model, you will see that EuGENia is getting confused because an AreaConnector is both an Element (as it inherits from Connector) *and* an AreaElement.
I'm not sure what is your desired result, but I've created a revised metamodel that doesn't have this issue. Connector is split into AbstractConnector (the concept) and Connector (the Element subclass). AreaConnector then inheirts from AbstractConnector and AreaElement, and EuGENia does not get confused anymore.
I can now create AreaConnectors cleanly between Views in an AreaDefinition, and then link pretty much anything else with a Connector.
Would this work for you?
-- Antonio

For my purpose and consistency to my project I needed to keep unmodified the metamodel, so I used a ECore2GMF.eol script to modify automatically the gmfmap before the editor generation. The final result is pretty like yours, we found two different ways. Thanks you.
No problem :-). I'll close the bug as invalid, then.

bug.short_desc: [EVL] Quick Fix is disabled(The editor shows the error but the Quick Fix is not enabled)

long_desc.thetext:
Thanks for the information, Mirco. I also managed to reproduce the issue by creating a similar editor and copying your EVL code. (I didn't see your report until now, sorry!)
The evl.emf.validation plugin dropped its markerResolution extension for some reason during the 1.0 release, strangely. I have restored the extension in SVN r2078 and it works for me now.
We'll provide updated binary distributions and update sites as soon as possible. Sorry for the trouble!

(In reply to comment #1) > Thanks for the information, Mirco. I also managed to reproduce the issue by > creating a similar editor and copying your EVL code. (I didn't see your > report until now, sorry!) > > The evl.emf.validation plugin dropped its markerResolution extension for > some reason during the 1.0 release, strangely. I have restored the extension > in SVN r2078 and it works for me now. > > We'll provide updated binary distributions and update sites as soon as > possible. Sorry for the trouble!
Oh, it seems we crossed paths just now :-D. Well, we'll let you know as soon as we update our binary distributions with the fix.
You great! Thank you!

I discussed this yesterday with Dimitris and it's actually not a bug. I checked again the documentation and it seems Mirco and I forgot to add the proper markerResolution extension to the plugin with the EVL scripts, as shown in step 4 in these instructions:
http://eclipse.org/epsilon/doc/articles/evl-gmf-integration/
Therefore, I have reverted the "fix": it's not a good idea to have the markerResolution extension in Epsilon itself, as we won't be able to specify a markerType and the EVL resolution generator will be called for every problem. This shouldn't pose any problems, but it could slow down Eclipse when doing other tasks (such as fixing Java code, for instance). Therefore, the original approach is better in the long run.
Mirco, sorry about the trouble :-/. You'll need to add the appropriate markerResolution extension (defined in org.eclipse.ui.ide, I believe) to the plugin with your EVL scripts.
Closing as invalid

bug.short_desc: Feature reorganization

long_desc.thetext:
Build Identifier:
As described by http://www.eclipse.org/forums/index.php/t/354919/ the features of Epsilon should be reconsidered.
Basically, development related plugins/tools (editors, wizards, views, etc) should become part of separate features.
So Epsilon can be deployed in applications without all these development plugins/tools, so the end users will not be 'bothered' by them. Advantage for the developers is that they could update the development features using nightly builds (or SVN) and use the deployed features (for the application) of the official releases.
While reconsidering the features, the 'external dependencies' could be kept in mind as well. So most parts Epsilon stays/becomes usable when, for example, GMF is not available. (See bug #378998 and bug #376293 for related work)
Reproducible: Always

Before starting work on this, I think we should reach an agreement on how to best split Epsilon by features.
Right now, we've got these smaller features:
- Concordance - Eugenia (including its Ant task) - EUnit Developer Tools: EUnit UI + model/file comparison components - EMF/GMF Live Validation (optional dependencies on GMF and OCL) - HUTN (EMC driver + core + UI)
And then there's the "Epsilon Core" feature, which has quite a few things. Let's try to classify them (dropping the org.eclipse.epsilon prefix):
- Parsing: antlr.postprocessor* - Base dependencies: commons, dependencies - Utilities: dt.epackageregistryexplorer (EPackage Registry), dt.exeed (Exeed and ModeLink) - ECL/EGL/EML/EOL/EPL/ETL/EVL/EWL/Flock: UI (e*l.dt*) + engine (e*l.engine) - EUnit engine (based on the EOL engine) - EMC drivers for BibTeX, CSV, XML and EMF-based models - Help - Epsilon perspective - Profiling - Ant tasks (.workflow)
That's quite a lot. How about splitting it like this:
- Epsilon Runtime: parsing + base deps + E*L/EUnit/Flock engines + EMF EMC driver - Epsilon Core SDK: help + perspective + UI for all the E*L languages + EPackage Registry + Exeed + ModeLink - Epsilon Extra EMC Drivers: BibTeX, CSV and XML EMC drivers - Epsilon Ant tasks
In that case, I suggest that we rename the EUnit Developer Tools feature to "EUnit SDK", to make it consistent. I think the smaller features can be kept as is, though.
How does this sound?

Sounds good to me. So will the EUnit UI components will be in the Epsilon Cores SDK group?
I also think that it would be a good idea to provide the stand alone example as part of the tools rather than an example. Maybe improve the code and give it a complete "API" feel. I am talking to my group directors to see if I can share our development which can be a starting point. If not maybe I can get some time to work on it again.

Thanks for kicking this off, Antonio.
The initial re-grouping that you suggest sounds good. I presume that you're proposing to split the Epsilon Core feature, and the other features (e.g. EuGENia and HUTN) remain as they are?
I think it perhaps makes sense to /not/ ship the EMF EMC driver as part of the Epsilon Runtime, as not all of our users are using EMF. Perhaps it would be preferable to include the XML driver as the standard instead? Dimitris will likely have a more informed view on this than I, though...

Nice points Louise. But to keep it as fair to all, perhaps just not include any EMC engine in the runtime. If I see it from a updatesite perspective you could have a "EMC Engines" feature and the user can choose which ones to get. And in the case of distributing applications/IDEs one can also choose what EMC engines to ship.

(In reply to comment #4) > Nice points Louise. But to keep it as fair to all, perhaps just not include any > EMC engine in the runtime. If I see it from a updatesite perspective you could > have a "EMC Engines" feature and the user can choose which ones to get. And in > the case of distributing applications/IDEs one can also choose what EMC engines > to ship.
Indeed, keep the core feature as 'core' as possible, so the user/developer is able to choose what additional features are required. This also keeps the dependencies of the core feature as low as possible.
The core feature could contain the E*L (engine) and depending plugins. All additional/optional plugins should be grouped in other features.
I suppose splitting it even further (A EOL feature, a EGL feature, etc) so the developer van pick what languages are used in his application, results in too much generation...

(In reply to comment #5) > I suppose splitting it even further (A EOL feature, a EGL feature, etc) so the > developer van pick what languages are used in his application, results in too > much generation...
generation = separation

I've chatted with Dimitris about this, and here are the use cases that we think we should be supporting right now:
- Some people use their own EMC driver (=> no drivers by default) - Some people build their own distribution of their own tool chains (no development tools such as EOL editor, etc) - Some people only want EuGENia (and its runtime dependencies)
Using the guiding principle of *minimising dependencies* (e.g. I should only be required to install GMF if I really want GMF), how about the following breakdown of the Epsilon Core feature?
1) Epsilon Runtime: parsing + base deps + E*L/EUnit/Flock engines 2) Epsilon Runtime EMF Integration: EMF EMC driver 3) Epsilon Runtime GMF Integration: EVL + GMF, EWL + GMF, etc. 4) Epsilon Core Dev Tools: help + perspective + UI for all the E*L languages 4) Epsilon EMF Dev Tools: EPackage Registry + Exeed + ModeLink + EMF compare int 6) Epsilon Extra EMC Drivers: Epsilon BibTeX, CSV and XML EMC drivers. (We think this should actually be one feature per driver). 7) Epsilon Ant tasks.
We're not sure whether (7) should be split into the other features. More specifically, could the Ant tasks be pushed into (1), (6) and the EuGENia feature?
What do you think?

(In reply to comment #5) > I suppose splitting it even further (A EOL feature, a EGL feature, etc) so the > developer van pick what languages are used in his application, results in too > much [separation]...
Long-term, I think this is a reasonable aim, and it is something that we have discussed. In the short-term, I think this might be too much of a change, particularly when we're not sure of the maintenance cost and user value of having more granular features.

(In reply to comment #4) > Nice points Louise. But to keep it as fair to all, perhaps just not include any > EMC engine in the runtime. If I see it from a updatesite perspective you could > have a "EMC Engines" feature and the user can choose which ones to get. And in > the case of distributing applications/IDEs one can also choose what EMC engines > to ship.
My concern with shipping no driver at all was that it might confuse new users. ("Hey, why can't I add any models to my run config?!").
However, I think you are right: it makes more sense for the users to choose whichever drivers they want. We can even provide some help text when we detect that no EMC drivers are available...

(In reply to comment #7) > 3) Epsilon Runtime GMF Integration: EVL + GMF, EWL + GMF, etc.
I currently use EVL without GMF (but use it in combination with EMF/GEF), is EVL (according to this proposal) only shipped with GMF dependencies? Or did I understand wrong?

(In reply to comment #10) > (In reply to comment #7) > > 3) Epsilon Runtime GMF Integration: EVL + GMF, EWL + GMF, etc. > > I currently use EVL without GMF (but use it in combination with EMF/GEF), is > EVL (according to this proposal) only shipped with GMF dependencies? Or did I > understand wrong?
Apologies, this wasn't very clear. I intended to say that (3) would contain any plugins that integrate Epsilon languages with GMF. So the EVL-GMF bridge and the EWL-GMF bridge. The engines for EVL, EWL (and all of the Epsilon languages) would reside in (1).

(In reply to comment #11) > I intended to say that (3) would contain any > plugins that integrate Epsilon languages with GMF. So the EVL-GMF bridge and > the EWL-GMF bridge. The engines for EVL, EWL (and all of the Epsilon languages) > would reside in (1).
Then I do not have problems with your proposal at all! (Can't wait till it gets released! ;) )

Created attachment 216664 First patch - still some issues left
Here's a first attempt for fixing this bug. It's pretty much as Louis suggested, but there are a few issues:
- eunit.engine depends on o.eclipse.core.runtime (it defines its own extension point, and the APIs for that are in there)
- flock.engine depends on emc.emf: is it really needed?
- the GMF feature depends on commons.dt, which is in the Core Dev Tools feature. Both features need commons.dt, though. What should we do?
- the Ant tasks depend on quite a few UI-facing plugins, due to their integration with the E*L debuggers and the profiler. Should they be optional dependencies?

(In reply to comment #13) > Created attachment 216664 [details] > First patch - still some issues left > > Here's a first attempt for fixing this bug. It's pretty much as Louis > suggested, but there are a few issues: > > - eunit.engine depends on o.eclipse.core.runtime (it defines its own extension > point, and the APIs for that are in there) >
Not an issue IMHO, if you define extensions you need the dependency
> - flock.engine depends on emc.emf: is it really needed? > Don't know the Epsilon "guts" good enough to comment
> - the GMF feature depends on commons.dt, which is in the Core Dev Tools > feature. Both features need commons.dt, though. What should we do? > I would guess the core dev tools are the "base" feature which all other depend on... I can only guess: "what if I need an editor without the engines?"... but I can not think o a scenario in which this is a requirement... so keep the dependency
> - the Ant tasks depend on quite a few UI-facing plugins, due to their > integration with the E*L debuggers and the profiler. Should they be optional > dependencies? If the dependencies are optional you could start getting errors when running the ant scripts... probably "no class def". From a usability point of view, IMHO, optional dependencies should enhance or add functionality, but if they are not present they should not generate errors. So the dependency should be required. However, I do see a scenario where u want the ant scripts but not the editors... but this would probably mean to go into the ant tasks and patch the code to just generate warnings, i.e. not crash, when the debugger or profiler is not found.
I suppose this issue is implemented and released in version 1.0, so it can be closed.
Thanks. This was indeed fixed in 1.0

long_desc.thetext:

child.~diagramNode.affixedParentSide := GmfGraph!Direction#NSEW;
should become:
child.~diagramNode.affixedParentSide := GmfGraph!Direction#NORTH; // or something similar
However, I'm not really familiar with this GMF property. Does this solution sound ok?

http://wiki.eclipse.org/GMF_Newsgroup_Q_and_A#Is_Affixed_Parent_Side_only_respected_on_creation.3F

bug.short_desc: Code highlighting and Variables view in Epsilon debuggers

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 218363 Screenshot demonstrating the two issues
Code highlighting does not appear to be accurate in Epsilon debuggers (see attached screenshot) - at least on Mac OS X. Also, in the variables view, the tree seems to be infinitely expandable (see values>values>values... sub-tree of the Variables view).

Fixed in SVN r1917.
The highlighting issue was due to relying on the columns reported by the currently running AST nodes in the frame stack. These columns report values that may be slightly surprising, as we might be running the executor for the '.' operator, for instance. The problem is that there's no easy way to obtain the final column for that node, so we simply highlighted until the end of the line.
This has been fixed by always highlighting from the start of the line to the end of the line. If we need something more accurate, we'll have to implement finding the final column for the AST node.
The endless expansion problem was due to the way primitive type wrappers are built: they contain a single "value" field with the actual primitive value. I tried adding immediate cycle detection in the Variables view, but that didn't work: accessing the "value" field through Field#get produces another (different) primitive wrapper, which is different from the current one and is not detected as a loop.
This has been fixed by never expanding primitive wrappers. I've left the cycle detection code anyway, as it might be useful in some other cases.
Fixed in 1.0

bug.short_desc: Eclipse stop responding with an recursive "import"

long_desc.thetext: If we create an EOL file and import the file itself, Eclipse will stop responding. It will stop responding again after reopen it. The only way I found to solve the problem was using a external editor to remove the recursive import. The same seems to happen when we import file A on file B, and import file B on file A.

(In reply to comment #0) > If we create an EOL file and import the file itself, Eclipse will stop > responding. It will stop responding again after reopen it. The only way I > found to solve the problem was using a external editor to remove the > recursive import. > The same seems to happen when we import file A on file B, and import file B > on file A.
This bug hit another user, as mentioned in this thread:
http://www.eclipse.org/forums/index.php?t=rview&goto=899646
I've committed a fix in SVN r1919.
I've added getParent/setParent methods to the IEolLibraryModule interface, which is the one that handles the imports, and a getSourceURI to the IModule interface. EolImport will try to look first for the script that is to be imported among its ancestors: if it finds it, it will reuse it instead of loading it again. That should work with any kind of circular or recursive import.
I've also added tests for:
1. Script tries to import itself. 2. Script A imports B and B imports A. 3. Script A imports B, B imports C and C imports A.
Fixed in 1.0

bug.short_desc: [EOL] Allow per-resource global variables

long_desc.thetext:
Currently, EOL's FrameStack provides a single frame for storing global variables. Increasingly, it seems as though some of the languages would benefit from a stack of frames for storing globals. In particular:
- EGL templates can call subtemplates, which might use different global variables. Currently EGL works around this limitation by shuffling global frames on and off EOL's FrameStack. See EglFrameStackManager and #347016 for more information.
- EUnit copies the variables created by @data operations into the global frame (see EUnitModule#applyDataBinding). In the future, it might be that the same data binding variables are not used for all tests, in which case a more general solution will be necessary.

We have decided to target the first stable release after moving to EMFT for this fix.
There may be some unit tests that can be re-used in EglFrameStackMangerTests.

In case we need a reminder of a possible solution, from Antonio's email:
If I have understood your code correctly, you shuffle snapshots of the stack frame for global variables into a stack as you call the main template and its subtemplates. I think we could fix this issue in a more general fashion, just by changing the lookup logic a little in FrameStack.
The main problem now is that all variables available in a protected stack frame must be either directly inside it or in the bottom stack frame. I suggest that we allow for several unprotected stack frames at the bottom of the stack, and start the global lookup from the topmost unprotected stack frame.
We'd need to add an attribute referencing the topmost contiguous unprotected stack frame in the FrameStack, and start global lookups from there. Suppose we had this stack frame, from bottom to top:
1. unprotected stack frame with System and null 2. unprotected stack frame with out (main template) and x 3. unprotected stack frame with out (subtemplate) and y 4. protected stack frame from calling f() 5. protected stack frame from calling g()
The topmost unprotected stack frame is 3. f() can access x, y, System, null and the copy of out which relates to the subtemplate. Same with g(). Note that the copy of out relating to the main template is "shadowed" here, as lookups start from 3.
This way, we only keep one stack, the usual stack frame. We'd need to add a new attribute with the topmost unprotected stack frame, though.
This shouldn't affect most E*L languages, as they are fine with one unprotected stack frame keeping all the global variables, but it would benefit EGL and perhaps EUnit. Right now all tests go through all data bindings, but they might not in the future.
Have the recent changes to FrameStack and Frame perhaps addressed these issues?
Louis and I already switched EGL to the new FrameStack implementation. EUnit doesn't use it yet, though: I'll adapt it now so we can close this bug.
Done: EUnit also uses the new support for multiple global stack frames now (SVN r1908). I think we can mark this bug as fixed now :-).
Thanks Antonio. I'm glad to see the back of this bug, although I did enjoy working together with you on this one!
This has been fixed in the latest interim version.
Fixed in 1.0

bug.short_desc: [Debugger] Show more information in the Variables view

long_desc.thetext:

bug.short_desc: [Eugenia] Minor inconsistencies in the workflow

long_desc.thetext:
Hi all,
While I was writing the Spanish book chapter on EuGENia, I noticed a few minor inconsistencies in the EuGENia workflow:
1. We have a menu entry called "Synchronize EMF gen model", and another called "Synchronize GMF GenModel". How about using "GenModel model" and "GMFGen model", instead?
2. The only way to invoke the "Synchronize EMF gen model" action is from the drop-down menu in Eclipse. The all-in-one "Generate GMF editor" doesn't call it, and for that reason, the Ant task doesn't either. Should we call it as well?
3. The ECore metamodel is exposed as "ECore" in some polishing transformations, and as "Ecore" in others. Should we use "ECore" everywhere?
4. The ECore metamodel is stored again in GenerateToolGraphMapDelegate. Shouldn't we set store=false in that case?
5. I already exposed with read=true and store=false the GmfGraph model in the FixGMFGen step. While we're at it, perhaps we should expose the other GMF models in the same way?
Except for step 3, I think most of these changes are safe. What are your thoughts on this?

#1 sounds OK
#2: yes - that's an omission in the current version
#3 could break existing code. We should probably use both (ECore could be an alias so that we preserve backward compatibility)
#4 rings a bell as something that was deliberate at the time - although I must admit I don't quite remember what the issue was when store was false
#5 sounds good to me
I'll work on #1-#3 and #5 then, and leave #4 as is.
I have implemented #1-#3 and #5. I'll wait until we get this into an interim release to update the Eugenia article in the website.

This has been fixed in the latest interim version.
Antonio: it should now be OK to update the Eugenia article accordingly.
Fixed in 1.0

I've marked the GMF dependency as optional, but we also need to drop the GMF dependency on the evl.emf.validation feature itself. Otherwise, it won't really make a difference.
Dimitris, Louis: are you OK with dropping that dependency from that feature? I guess GMF users would probably install Eugenia anyway, and that would still pull GMF into Epsilon's dependencies.

The evl.emf.validation feature doesn't declare any strong > dependency on OCL. In fact, its only plugin has OCL as an optional dependency > :-/. Perhaps we're getting the OCL dependency from some other feature. > > Which features did you install?
When thinking about it, I suppose that it is not a problem at run-time. But it was a problem when compiling EMF validation (to prevent/fix some of the other bugs I reported). The OCL support code (obviously) requires OCL installed when compiling.

bug.short_desc: Context operations broken for objects that implement Iterable

long_desc.thetext:
Hi Maarten,
Well, this is a bit of a dilemma :-/. If we don't wrap the Iterable as a Sequence, we won't get all the methods in the CollectionOperatorContributor that are normally associated with collections. But if we do, you won't be able to use your context operation.
We could try to modify the CollectionOperatorContributor so it would work on Iterable objects, though, or split it into an IterableOperatorContributor and a CollectionOperatorContributor if that wasn't possible. In that case, we might be able to get away with not wrapping Iterable objects.
I'll have a shot at it and let you know how it goes.
Cheers, Antonio

Fixed in SVN r1859.
I've revised the old CollectionOperationContributor so it's based on Iterable and not on Collection, and I've added a few tests for the new Iterable-specific bits I've introduced.
Thanks to this, it should no longer be necessary to wrap Iterable objects. I've tried calling a context operation on an Iterable object (as in this report) and it works now :-).
Pretty much every operation in the old CollectionOperatorContributor is supported, except clone(), as there's no reliable way to create a clone from an Iterable object. I have added a size() operation to the contributor, for convenience and consistency.
A few warnings:
- Some of these operations might be quite inefficient for Iterable objects that are not Collections, as they only provides sequential access.
- Iterators will still be wrapped, though, so be careful!
I'm not sure how to document this in the Epsilon book, though. Iterable is not mentioned anywhere in the EOL type system. Hmm.
This has been fixed in the latest interim version.
Fixed in 1.0

bug.short_desc: Abusive cast of PrintStream to ByteBufferTeePrintStream in EUnitXMLFormatter

long_desc.thetext:
When i try to use the demo project of EUnit for ATL (available at http://dev.eclipse.org/svnroot/modeling/org.eclipse.epsilon/trunk/examples/org.eclipse.epsilon.eunit.examples.atl) using the equinox application dispatcher, i fall in a cast exception when the ant task try to generate the Junit report. As i am calling the ant task from Ant, there is no way to force the field fGenerateReport of the instance of EUnitTask to be false, even in calling the method setReport.
The command is use is the following : java -jar $ECLIPSE_HOME/plugins/org.eclipse.equinox.launcher_*.jar -application org.eclipse.ant.core.antRunner at the root of the project. In order to use it, you must rename eunit.xml to build.xml, and specify "run-tests" as the default for the project.
The bug is located between the lines 77 and 80 in EUnitXMLFormatter (plugin org.eclipse.epsilon.eunit.engine, package org.eclipse.epsilon.internal.eunit.xml). It looks like the module used has kept his initial value (System.out), and has never been updated to an instance of ByteBufferTeePrintStream ...

That's strange: it should update those fields to a ByteBufferTeePrintStream as soon as it runs the root test. Lines 320-325 of EUnitModule do just that:
if (node.isRootTest()) { // We need to wrap the original streams to capture all their output, for the JUnit-like reports. // We can't do it in #initialize(), as the EUnit Ant task changes stdout/stderr to point to the // Epsilon console in the beforeCase EUnitTestListener handler. getContext().setOutputStream(new ByteBufferTeePrintStream(getContext().getOutputStream())); getContext().setErrorStream(new ByteBufferTeePrintStream(getContext().getErrorStream()));
Have you tried setting the "report" attribute to "false" in the Ant script, and avoiding the "toDir" attribute? The "toDir" attribute implies "report" to be "true" and overrides the "report = false" setting.
I have installed the latest interim version of Epsilon in an Eclipse Juno 4.2M7 installation, and I have run the tasks with:
java \ -jar ~/bin/eclipse-with-epsilon/plugins/org.eclipse.equinox.launcher_*.jar \ -application org.eclipse.ant.core.antRunner \ -data ~/workspaces/epsilon/ -buildfile eunit.xml
This reproduces your issue. However, if I set report="true" in the <epsilon.eunit> element in the eunit.xml file, I get this instead:
[epsilon.eunit - atl.eunit] Test root {} failed with status ERROR: Workbench has not been created yet. [epsilon.eunit - atl.eunit] Global result: ERROR
It seems that your issue is due to this early error. EUnit isn't even getting to run the root test, and that causes the cast exception later on. Looking at the log file of the workspace, I got a stack trace of the related exception:
Caused by: java.lang.IllegalStateException: Workbench has not been created yet. at org.eclipse.ui.PlatformUI.getWorkbench(PlatformUI.java:92) at org.eclipse.epsilon.common.dt.console.EpsilonConsole.<init>(EpsilonConsole.java:42) at org.eclipse.epsilon.common.dt.console.EpsilonConsole.getInstance(EpsilonConsole.java:63) at org.eclipse.epsilon.eol.dt.launching.EclipseContextManager.loadIo(EclipseContextManager.java:88) at org.eclipse.epsilon.eol.dt.launching.EclipseContextManager.setup(EclipseContextManager.java:66) at org.eclipse.epsilon.workflow.tasks.EUnitTask.beforeCase(EUnitTask.java:196) at org.eclipse.epsilon.eunit.EUnitModule.fireBeforeCase(EUnitModule.java:507) at org.eclipse.epsilon.eunit.EUnitModule.runSuiteInternal(EUnitModule.java:318) at org.eclipse.epsilon.eunit.EUnitModule.runSuite(EUnitModule.java:164) at org.eclipse.epsilon.eunit.EUnitModule.execute(EUnitModule.java:136) at org.eclipse.epsilon.workflow.tasks.ExecutableModuleTask.executeImpl(ExecutableModuleTask.java:193) ... 36 more
It appears that we need to either detect we're running in a headless build, or force the workbench plugin to be loaded at the right time. I'd need more time to look at this, though.

Fixed in SVN r1842.
Two well-placed "if (PlatformUI.isWorkbenchRunning())" seem to have fixed this. I have managed to run the EUnit tests in the .atl example just fine with the same command as before.
The only caveat is that you need to set derived="false" on the atl.saveModel Ant task. I have updated the example to reflect this. Otherwise, that task will throw a NullPointerException at line 136 of the SaveModelTask, for some reason. If you need derived="true", please talk with the ATL developers about it.

Thanks for your reactivity !!
Did you published your patched version of EUnit on the Eclipse Update Site ? Or do i have to install EUnit from the sources ?

The fix is right now only available from the SVN sources. We'll probably have another interim release in a few weeks or so.
Still, the changes have been relatively minor, so I think you should be able to fix it by updating to yesterday's interim release and unpacking the attached file to $ECLIPSE_HOME/dropins. If you could confirm that it worked for you, it'd be great :-).

works perfectly for me !!

bug.short_desc: isOfKind and isOfType are prone to name conflicts with relative type references

long_desc.thetext:
Fixed in SVN 1866.
I have modified classForName so it will look first into the EPackage of the first element of the model, and only scan the EPackage registry if it doesn't find the type there.
That should get rid of most of the naming conflicts :-).
I suspect that the problem is related to InMemoryEmfModel rather than to AbstractEmfModel. I'm syncing my local copy after a long period of inactivity and will investigate when I'm in sync.
I'll drop back into the debugger and see what's going on, then :-).

I'm not sure which of these approaches would be best to solve the issue:
- Have ExeedEditor create the InMemoryEmfModel passing the top EPackage. This would solve the current issue, but more instances may pop up elsewhere in the code.
- Whenever a list of EPackages is explicitly indicated in the constructor to InMemoryEmfModel, set up our own EPackageRegistryImpl with those EPackages, while still delegating to the global EPackage registry if required.
- Always set up a new EPackageRegistryImpl in the InMemoryEmfModel constructors, delegating to the global EPackage registry. If a list of EPackages is provided, populate that registry with those EPackages.
I prefer the second and third approaches. The third approach may be more predictable in practice, but the second approach feels safer. What do you think?

Created attachment 217409 Revert first fix and apply second approach to fix InMemoryEmfModel
I tried the third approach, but it broke quite a few tests.
However, the second approach fixes the problem (after reverting the original "fix") and doesn't break any tests. I've attached the patch on top of the latest SVN revision.

Created attachment 217442 Revised patch which doesn't break the "extraPackages" extension point attribute
Seems that the attached patch broke the "extraPackages" EWL extension point attribute. This revised patch fixes that.
I've reverted the first fix in this thread on SVN r1869 and applied the June 15th patch on SVN r1870. Marking again as fixed.
This has been fixed in the latest interim version.
Fixed in 1.0

attachment.desc: Revert first fix and apply second approach to fix InMemoryEmfModel
Revised patch which doesn't break the "extraPackages" extension point attribute

bug.short_desc: [Debugger] Clicking on a stack frame does not jump to its current statement

long_desc.thetext:
Unlike the Java debugger included with Eclipse, clicking on a stack frame does not show the line it is currently running. This can be important when debugging EOL programs with many nested calls, or calls from unexpected locations.
We should implement the same behaviour for the E*L debuggers, using the getCurrentStatement() and getEntryPoint() methods of the Frame interface.
Fixed in SVN r1882.
This has been fixed in the latest interim version.
Fixed in 1.0

bug.short_desc: EpsilonTestSuite fails on test case "testRemove" from CollectionsTests.eol

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 190676 Patch which implements a 2-phase lookup process
This patch implements phase 1 of the JLS method resolution process, but we'd still be missing phase 3 (varargs). I really think we should stick to Class#getMethod.

I'm not sure if this is helpful, but on my Windows installation this test passes! Maybe due to a different version of Java? I'm running:
Java(TM) SE Runtime Environment (build 1.6.0_15-b03) Java HotSpot(TM) Client VM (build 14.1-b02, mixed mode, sharing)
I'm running OpenJDK 6 on Linux. And you're right: I ran the tests today on Windows 7 and this one passed :-/.

One of our users has been bitten by this problem, according to this thread:
http://www.eclipse.org/forums/index.php/mv/msg/351807/872040/#msg_872040
Dimitris, Louis: could you have another look at the patch?

Antonio,
Thanks for continuing to drive this forward
I agree with your diagnosis. I've investigated whether we can use Class#getMethod, but sadly this doesn't help. According to [1,2], Class#getMethod doesn't correctly manage auto-boxing and it seems we'd have to continue to maintain our own logic for this.
Consequently I believe your patch on comment 1 is the solution we should use. I've rebased this patch on HEAD, added some unit tests, and refactored out some duplication that has been in ReflectionUtil for a little while.
[1] - http://royontechnology.blogspot.co.uk/2010/10/issue-of-autoboxing-and-reflection.html [2] - http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1894740/any-solution-for-class-getmethod-reflection-and-autoboxing

(In reply to comment #6) > Created attachment 215718 [details] > Rebased Antonio's patch on top of HEAD > > Latest version of Antonio's solution attached. > > @Dimitris, @Antonio: could you take a look, and give a +1 if we can push this > forward?
+1

(In reply to comment #7) > (In reply to comment #6) > > @Dimitris, @Antonio: could you take a look, and give a +1 if we can push this > > forward? > > +1 > > The patch looks good to me. Did that fix testRemove at last?

(In reply to comment #8) > It did on Mac OS X. When I get home, I'll check on Windows (which I think > implements Class#getMethod differently, judging by comment 2).

(In reply to comment #9) > (In reply to comment #8) > > It did on Mac OS X. When I get home, I'll check on Windows (which I think > > implements Class#getMethod differently, judging by comment 2). > > Confirming that the attached patch works on Windows (XP, Java 7 update 4).
