bug.short_desc: [Flock] Migration should not copy elements of a type that does not belong to the original metamodel

long_desc.thetext: This is due to a bug in the way in which Flock establishes type mappings. Currently, model elements stored in models external to the original model are incorrectly included in the computation that identifies type mappings.

I've fixed this by ensuring that only the direct contents of a model are used when identifying type mappings.
The patch is now in SVN.
This has been fixed in the latest interim version.
Fixed in 1.0

bug.short_desc: [EGL] Should use given pretty printers

long_desc.thetext:
Currently, EGL doesn't use pretty printers set on its context. Consequently printing EMF model elements does not use the built-in EmfPrettyPrinter.
For example:
[% EObject.first.all.println(); %]
Produces the Java string representation, such as:
org.eclipse.emf.ecore.impl.EClassImpl@536d3814 (name: NamedElement) (instanceClassName: null) (abstract: true, interface: false)
Rather than the pretty printed version:
EClass [name=NamedElement, instanceClassName=null, instanceClass=null, defaultValue=null, instanceTypeName=null, abstract=true, interface=false, ]
This was caused by EGL not copying the PrettyPrinterManager to preprocessor module's context. I've fixed this, and added a setPrettyPrinterManager to IEolContext and EolContext along the way.
Thanks! Changing this to resolved/fixed as per http://www.eclipse.org/epsilon/doc/articles/resolved-bugs/
This has been fixed in the latest interim version.
Fixed in 1.0

bug.short_desc: [EMC] XML Driver ANT task does not respect read/store attributes

long_desc.thetext: The ANT task for loading an XML model currently ignores the values of the read / store attributes, and uses the defaults instead.
Just a small oversight in the ANT task implementation.
Fix checked into SVN.
This has been fixed in the latest interim version.
Fixed in 1.0

bug.short_desc: Resetting a module does not clear operations

long_desc.thetext: It looks like this is because #getOperations() caches its result, but the cache isn't cleared in #reset().
This has been fixed in the latest interim version.
Fixed in 1.0

bug.short_desc: Missing plugins when installing only 'Epsilon Core'

long_desc.thetext:
Build Identifier: I20110613-1736
Cannot complete the install because one or more required items could not be found. Software currently installed: Epsilon Core (Incubation) 0.9.1.201204060319 (org.eclipse.epsilon.feature.feature.group 0.9.1.201204060319) Missing requirement: Epsilon ANT Workflow (Incubation) 0.9.1.201204060319 (org.eclipse.epsilon.workflow 0.9.1.201204060319) requires 'bundle org.eclipse.epsilon.emc.hutn 0.0.0' but it could not be found Cannot satisfy dependency: From: Epsilon Core (Incubation) 0.9.1.201204060319 (org.eclipse.epsilon.feature.feature.group 0.9.1.201204060319) To: org.eclipse.epsilon.workflow [0.9.1.201204060319]
When I include 'Human Usable Textual Notation' the dependency error is gone.
Reproducible: Always
Thanks for reporting this. As Epsilon has grown substantially over the last few years, I guess we'll need to rethink the modularisation of the offering into Eclipse features.
@Louis: That would be an option. @Antonio: Would it perhaps make sense to remove this method altogether?

(In reply to comment #3) > @Louis: That would be an option. > @Antonio: Would it perhaps make sense to remove this method altogether?
I'd rather keep it, even if it has to go to a separate plug-in. I think it's quite convenient for testing, and we have some unit tests in .workflow using it.
I believe I'd only have to create a new plug-in with an additional EOL operation contributor, so it should be pretty simple. Shall I do that?

(In reply to comment #5) > Thanks! Sounds good to me. Are the operations of RunTargetOperationContributor > meant to be context-less? If so contributesTo() should be modified as follows > > @Override > public boolean contributesTo(Object target) { > // return true; > return EolNoType.NoInstance.equals(target); > } > > (If you do this, please update the eol.engine plugin from the SVN first)
Yes, I've changed the EUnit operation contributors in workflow and eol.engine to be context-less, as that was my intention.
Sadly, I don't think I can split apart the operation to a separate plugin, as I'd need access to the "module" field of the EUnitTask. Splitting it into an extension point would be a bit overkill, though.
How about marking the HUTN dependency as optional and using reflection to create the HutnModel and initialize it? It's not the kind of operation you should be calling inside a loop all the time anyway.
Using reflection sounds like a good idea. I agree that an extension point is probably an overkill for this.
Done! I've marked the emc.hutn dependency in workflow as optional, and I'm using reflection for loadHutn now. It passes all tests, so it should work fine :-).
Thanks chaps. Installing Epsilon Core on top of a fresh Eclipse works fine now, so I'm marking this as fixed.
This has been fixed in the latest interim version.
Fixed in 1.0

bug.short_desc: Protected region id cannot contain /

long_desc.thetext:
Build Identifier:
I am using some 'protected regions' using the out.preserve() operation.
Some of these regions do not seem to work (their content is being overridden each time). Finally, I noticed the pattern/problem, it seems ids containing a / are not working: [code] out.preserve("//", "", "additional class members/functions", true, "") [/code]
I can live with that. But, maybe EGL should give an error when illegal characters are used to warn the developer? Or at least, the Epsilon book should mention this, I think.
Reproducible: Always
Many thanks for reporting this.
We can be more flexible wrt to the characters that can be used in identifiers. Currently, symbols (other that underscore) are not allowed, but it should be trivial to support other symbols.
I've changed the regular expression used to match identifiers in protected regions to be more lenient: any characters can now be used in an identifier.
This has been fixed in the latest interim version.
Fixed in 1.0

bug.short_desc: Pasting texts containing characters that are automatically closed goes wrong

long_desc.thetext:

When pasting texts containing characters that are automatically closed in an Epsilon editor, the resulting text has the closing characters added.
For example: - paste [%test%] in the editor and [%test%]] is actually pasted. - paste "" in the editor and """ is actually pasted - paste ( in the editor and () is actually pasted
It is only reproducible when the first character is automatically closed: when i paste <space>" the result is <space>" as well.
The description seems a bit cryptic, so hopefully it is clear enough...

bug.short_desc: Matching URIs

long_desc.thetext:
When comparing URIs of items from different models, the comparison is very specific and minor differences can result in no match. As an example ' ' and '%20' in file paths will cause URIs not to match. If the URI is a file protocol then the URIs could be resolved to the file reference to determine if URIs are pointing at the same destination file.
This was found when there were slight differences between the URI used in the run configuration for a model, and the URI encoded in XMI, which pointed to that model
This has now been fixed in the SVN. Please feel free to reopen if it doesn't work for you as expected.
This has been fixed in the latest interim version.
Fixed in 1.0

bug.short_desc: [EGL] TemplateFactory#load changes the path from which templates are loaded

long_desc.thetext:
For the following directory structure:
Driver.egl first/First.egl second/Second.egl
where Driver.egl contains:
[%=TemplateFactory.load('first/First.egl').process()%] [%=TemplateFactory.load('second/Second.egl').process()%]
EGL throws a FileNotFoundException, while trying to load 'second/Second.egl'. It appears that EGL is trying to load a template at 'first/second/Second.egl', which seems to indicate that TemplateFactory#load has the (counter-intuitive) side-effect of changing the location from which templates are loaded.

This was caused by EglModule's execute method, which was calling TemplateFactory#setRoot whenever a template (or subtemplate) was executed. I've changed the execute method to only change the root of the TemplateFactory if it has not been set already (using a new method: TemplateFactory#initialiseRoot).
I've added a regression test to cover this: InvokingSubtemplates.java
Fix committed to SVN.
Fixed in 1.0

bug.short_desc: [Eugenia] Add polygon and SVG figures and allow for omitting labels

long_desc.thetext:
I've been working on an improved version of our flowchart example for a chapter in a Spanish book about modelling technologies, but I have an important constraint: due to space constraints, I can't use a polishing transformation, and custom figures are out of the scope of the book.
Since ellipses and boxes wouldn't quite cut it for this example, I thought it'd be best to slightly improve Eugenia with a few new built-in shapes and finally add support for removing labels from a node. Being forced to use a polishing transformation just to remove something which shouldn't have been there always felt a bit irritating, after all.
Examples:
- This would draw a triangle:
@gmf.node(figure='polygon', polygon.x="0 10 5", polygon.y="0 0 5")
- This would draw a SVG file in a plugin:
@gmf.node(figure='svg', svg.uri='platform:/plugin/my.plugin/icons/icon.svg')
- This would omit creating a label for the node (but not its attributes):
@gmf.node(label.placement='none')
I've committed code which implements all these cases to SVN. SVG support is a little special, as it depends on the experimental GMF SDK. I also needed to extend the FixGMFGen built-in transformation so it could add the o.e.gmf.runtime.lite and o.e.gmf.runtime.lite.svg plugins to the GmfGen's requiredPlugins whenever a SVGFigure had been used somewhere in the GmfGraph model.
Dimitris, Louis: could you take a look? The Eugenia regression tests still pass as usual, so I think I haven't broken anything, but just in case.

Marking as fixed, as I just committed it to SVN.
BTW, it'd be nice if we could get an interim release shortly after closing this bug, so I could be sure there was a prepackaged version of Eugenia for the example in the book.
Thanks for implementing this. I've had a look at it and it looks fine to me. I'll try to release a new interim version that integrates this within the next few days.
This has now been integrated in the latest interim version.
I have listed these properties in the Eugenia article in the website.
Fixed in 1.0

bug.short_desc: Resource not found: "/project:/ProjectName/PathToModel" when applying EVL quick fix

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: 20090619-0625
Steps To Reproduce: 1. Define a plugin with an .evl file with constraints and a quick fix. 2. Create a diagram of the validated model which violates one of those constraints. 3. Validate using Edit > Validate. 4. Right click in one of the problem markers in the Problems view. 5. Select Quick Fix. 6. An error message appears saying that the model file does not exist, but with a wrong path: "/project:/Project/PathToModelFile". 7. If dismissed, only the default Ignore quick fix appears.
More information: This issue has been commented in the Epsilon mailing list. I'll copy and paste from my message:
I thought it might be in the same category of issues as bug #285559, so I looked around with the debugger and found two problems.
- The method getElementResourceLocation of the class org.eclipse.epsilon.evl.emf.validation.GmfMarkerResolver returns platform URIs to the workspace files, but they don't have the "resource" segment, so they look like this:
project:/NameOfProject/PathToMyModelFile
rather than this:
project:/resource/NameOfProject/PathToMyModelFile
Louis Rose has agreed that this might be an omission. However, there is another issue which warrants further attention, and which is the true reason for this bug report:
- The method getEditingDomain of the class org.eclipse.epsilon.evl.emf.validation.EmfMarkerResolver uses the previous platform URI by creating a Path from it. Reading the Javadocs for Path, I gather that it expects an absolute filesystem path, not a platform URI, so that's where the "/project:/foo/bar" part comes from.
Apparently, the existing code should work with platform URIs, as it has been taken verbatim from EMF, but it doesn't.
I've attached a patch which solves both issues. The second issue is circumvented by using a FileLocator to convert the platform URI to an absolute path in the local filesystem, and then use (...).getfile(new Path(path)).
Created attachment 143791 Quick and dirty patch which solves the two issues described
I've had a quick look at this, but it needs some further investigation, which I'll carry out in the next couple of days.

I've been able to recreate this bug both in a GMF diagram editor and in the EMF tree editor. I'm suggesting the attached patch, which tidies up the code submitted by Antonio.
I've no idea why the code taken from EMF no longer works. Perhaps it is something to do with a change to URI#toPlatformString()?
Dimitrios, would you take a look at this when you have a chance?
Created attachment 143900 Slightly tidier patch
I've applied the patch and committed to the SVN. The fix will appear in 0.8.7
Fixed in 0.8.7

bug.short_desc: [EOL] Implement Map literals

long_desc.thetext:

Here is a patch which adds Map literals to EOL, including several test cases for the EOL acceptance suite. Please note that:
- To make the patch more readable, it does not include the code generated by ANTLR. After applying the patch, ANTLR will have to be run again in all E*L languages.
- The "a = b = c" ambiguity has been resolved by using additiveExpression for the key, and logicalExpression for the value. Therefore, keys cannot use logical or relational operators unless between parenthesis, and "1 = 2 = 3" will be split into 1 (the key) and 2 = 3 (the value).

bug.short_desc: assertEquals fails with large Long values

long_desc.thetext:
I had a look at the code of assertEquals and noticed something interesting. The current implementation relies on EolObjectComparator, which compares two numbers like this:
return ((Number) o1).doubleValue() == ((Number) o2).doubleValue();
This line has one problem: large integer values (likely Long values) will be rounded down, making different integers seem to be equal.
Indeed, adding this line inside testCompareIntegers() in the ComparisonTests.eol file in the EOL acceptance tests project makes the test fail:
assertEquals(9223372036854775807l == 9223372036854775806l, true);
To fix this, I propose that the Java Language Specification is followed more closely, particularly regarding sections 5.6.1 ("unary numeric promotion") and 5.6.2 ("binary numeric promotion"), in the NumberUtil and EolObjectComparator classes:
http://java.sun.com/docs/books/jls/third_edition/html/conversions.html#5.6.1

Created attachment 191322 Patch which fixes the problem and makes NumberUtil follow JLS 5.6.1 and 5.6.2
Here is a patch which reimplements sections 5.6.1 and 5.6.2 of the Java Language Specification to fix the problem and heavily reduce the number of casts in NumberUtil.
The above patch has been integrated for a while. Closing this bug as fixed.
Fixed in 0.9.1

attachment.desc: Patch which fixes the problem and makes NumberUtil follow JLS 5.6.1 and 5.6.2

bug.short_desc: [Patch] Allow EWL to load additional EPackages into packages registry

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 187692 Patch which adds the 'extraPackages' attribute to the EWL extension point
I have been working on using EWL to perform update transformations in UML2 models annotated with stereotypes from the MARTE profile [1]. I have run into some limitations in EWL, which I think would be solved with the attached patch.
To create these models, I have used Papyrus [2]. My update transformations work with performance annotations, so these UML2 models include stereotypes from the MARTE profile, also implemented within the Papyrus project [3].
The created models include the standard UML2 model, and some instances of the stereotypes in the MARTE profile. Th MARTE stereotype applications include links to the UML2 constructs they decorate, but not the other way around.
I need to define wizards on UML2 activities to annotate the actions within with their inferred performance requirements. In this context, I have run into some issues with EWL:
* If I use namespaceURI='(UML2 URI)', I can right-click on an UML2 Activity and the wizard shows up, but the wizard does not work, as the MARTE types are not available. From the source, it looks like EWL loads the model using the namespace URI of the top EPackage of the first EObject selected. Therefore, if I select an UML2 activity, only the UML2 metamodel and its dependencies will be available. UML2 does not depend on MARTE, so the MARTE types are not available.
* If I use namespaceURI='(MARTE URI)', the wizard would work, but nothing shows up if the user right-clicks on an UML2 Activity.
I have created a sample plug-in project to illustrate the issue. The project includes a base metamodel and a separate metamodel used to "annotate" elements of the first metamodel, in the fashion of UML2 and MARTE. The project includes a simple EWL wizard which will throw an exception related to this issue when following these steps:
1. Start a self-hosted Eclipse with the sample plug-in installed. 2. Open the sample model with the Sample Reflective Ecore Model. 3. Right click on the Element instance. 4. Try to use the 'Annotate with Foo' wizard.
The error is averted if the ElementComment instance is right-clicked first, or if the Exeed editor is used. I suppose that in the first case the annotation metamodel is silently loaded into the underlying resource's package registry. In the second case, the Exeed editor seems to load pretty much all available metamodels into the registry.
I have also attached a simple patch which aims to solve this issue. Going back to the UML2+MARTE case, the basic idea is to still use the UML2 URI for namespaceURI, but tell EWL to add the MARTE package into the package registry as well. To do this, I have extended the EWL extension point with a new attribute, which takes a comma-separated list of the namespace URIs of the EPackages to be added to the package registry, after adding the metamodel in the namespaceURI attribute and its dependencies. These EPackages are not used to determine if the wizard is applicable to a model element.
Finally, I have also included a model using UML2 and MARTE, created with the Papyrus toolset. This is the model I'm using for testing the algorithms and the wizards.
[1]: http://www.omgmarte.org/ [2]: http://www.eclipse.org/modeling/mdt/papyrus/ [3]: http://www.eclipse.org/forums/index.php?t=msg&th=203094&start=0&S=cd4e0fd5805741db797c9517e02b3ecc
Created attachment 187693 Sample plug-in project demonstrating the issue
Created attachment 187694 Sample UML2 model annotated with the MARTE profile

Created attachment 187849 Version 2 of the patch

Thanks for reporting this. I'll have a look at the patch and integrate it within the next couple of days.

I experience a very similar bug, actually so similar that it might be reasonable to reopen this one.
= General Description =
When an ETL transformation is fired from an Ant task, epsilon.loadModel fails when refering to the file by <parameter name="foo" file="model/foo.xmi">, but is successful with <parameter name="foo" value="../fooProject/model/foo.xmi">
= Experienced Behaviour (Problem) =
A model of the Kingdom of Saxony (Saxony.xmi, metamodel kingdom.ecore) is to be transformed to a republic (Republic_of_Saxony.xmi, metamodel republic.ecore) by an ETL transformation.
The transformation is governed by an Ant task (adapted from oo2db_launch.xml supplied with Epsilon´s OO2DB example) which contains the following loadModel entry (existing instance model that is used as input, output model directive is similar and not shown here):
<epsilon.loadModel name="kingdom" type="EMF"> <parameter name="modelFile" file="model/Saxony.xmi"/> <parameter name="metamodelUri" value="kingdom"/> <parameter name="readOnLoad" value="true"/> <parameter name="storeOnDisposal" value="false"/> </epsilon.loadModel>
Running it (Run as -> 1 Ant Build) gives the following console output (see attachment for complete output including stack trace):
Buildfile: /home/fab/workspace-epsilon/revolution_Transformation /revolution_launch.xml
loadModels: [epsilon.loadModel] Internal error: org.eclipse.emf.ecore.resource.Resource$IOWrappedException: Resource '/home /fab/workspace-epsilon/revolution_Transformation/model/Saxony.xmi' does not exist.
The relative path from the launch script is correctly expanded towards the absolute path shown, which is perfectly correct (everything is fine with the file, see next section).
= Experienced Behaviour (Workaround) =
Inspired by the solutions to the similar problem reported in this bug report here (the one I'm jsut adding a comment to), I've figured out that altering the modelFile entries fixes the problem. The following works and produces a correct result:
<parameter name="modelFile" value="../revolution_Transformation/model/Saxony.xmi"/>
But neighter
<parameter name="modelFile" file="../revolution_Transformation/model/Saxony.xmi"/>
nor
<parameter name="modelFile" value="model/Saxony.xmi"/>
= Expected Behaviour =
The workaround should not be needed, (Problem) should work as well as (Workaround).
= Let´s Add Some Confusion =
Let´s get back to the state with the 'wrong' launch script. That´s the ETL script (nothing wrong with that so far):
pre { 'ETL starts'.println(); }
post { 'ETL done'.println(); }
-- simple mapping: each and every creature becomes an equal citizen rule Dragon2Citizen transform d : kingdom!Dragon to c : republic!Citizen { 'dragon2citizen'.println(); c.name := d.name; }
There is one dragon in the source model.
Actually the problem described in the above section only shows up *exactly* every second time I run the Ant script. It takes turns with a *different* problem. Every second time, the program seems to run successfully (even though the launch script is 'wrong'):
Buildfile: /home/fab/workspace-epsilon/revolution_Transformation /revolution_launch.xml
loadModels:
main: [epsilon.etl - revolution.etl] ETL starts [epsilon.etl - revolution.etl] ETL done
BUILD SUCCESSFUL Total time: 309 milliseconds
Please note that dragon2citizen is never called. If the loadModel directive of the output model is 'wrong', no output model (not even an empty one) is generated. If its loadmodel directive is correct (but still not the one of the source model), an empty model is generated.
I don´t have any idea how the turn-taking behaviour comes into play. It is however fixed by using 'correct' loadModel directives for both entries: a correct republic model inhabited by a single citizen is delivered and the following console output is produced *every time it is run* (no strange take-turns here):
main: [epsilon.etl - revolution.etl] ETL starts [epsilon.etl - revolution.etl] dragon2citizen [epsilon.etl - revolution.etl] ETL done
= System Details =
* Epsilon Core 0.9.1.201107251201 * Eclipse Modeling Tools, Indigo Service Release 2, Build id: 20120216-1857 * Linux AMD64, fully updated Ubuntu 10.04.4 LTS
Please let me know whether I can provide you with additional information to investigate the issue or help in other ways! Thank you very much!

long_desc.thetext:

Occurrence:

Reproduction:

bug.short_desc: forAll() returns true if applied to empty collection

long_desc.thetext:
The forAll operation returns true if used on an empty collection. For example:
var seq : Sequence; seq.forAll(p | p.direction = 1).println();
prints true.
In my opinion any test operations on empty collections should return false.
I haven't tried if the same behavior is seen in the other test functions.
Horacio

I'm actually against this change.
Conventionally, any universal quantification on the empty set is vacously true. (See: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universal_quantification#The_empty_set)

I don't think this is a bug, either.
From a strictly formal standpoint, "for all x that meet y, z is true" is trivially true if y is always false.
Actually, think of it: when would that statement be false? It would be false if there was some x that met y for which z was false. However, there isn't *any* such x (there aren't *any* x at all!), so it must be true.
(It's interesting to talk about formal logic in an Eclipse bug. :-D)
Dimitris, Horacio: may I close this report as "not a bug"? I think the current behaviour is mathematically sound.
+1 for closing this as "invalid"
There it goes :-). Sorry Horacio, but you'll need to test that the collection is empty yourself if you'd like to have that kind of behaviour.
Yep its fine. I was going to debate some.. but at the end of the day keeping it within standard formal logic rationale.
Closed as invalid.

bug.short_desc: Extended properties on nested sequences are silently discarded

long_desc.thetext:
Build Identifier: 20100218-1602
There are problems when unwrapping an object and then re-wrapping it for just one operation, just to remove the wrapping right after evaluating the expression. Namely, the extended properties that were set on the wrapper will be discarded.
This is a problem when adding sequences to a sequence: by default, PointExecutor will attempt to perform the call using reflection and unwrapped types. This makes add() add an unwrapped element to the sequence, which later on shows the above problem after being wrapped again and again with different EolSequence instances.
There are two possible solutions:
* first try calling with wrapped values, and then try unwrapped values: this fixes this problem, does not lose any of the available API, and avoids the useless unwrapping and rewrapping that gets done here. But I might be missing something here: is there a reason why unwrapped values should be tried first, like now?
* change EolTypeWrapper so that when wrapping an object that was wrapped before, the original wrapper will be returned. This uses more memory, but it might solve the problem in a more general way.
I have attached a sample program which illustrates the problem: trying to set an extended property for the first nested sequence in a sequence works if it is built using Sequence{Sequence{1}}, but not if created as Sequence{} and then extended with add(1).
I have also attached two patches which attempt to fix the problem in the above two ways. I'm not sure which one is better, but I think it's the first one, since it makes the example program print exactly the same thing for Sequence{Sequence{1}} and Sequence {} followed by add(1).
Reproducible: Always
Steps to Reproduce: 1. Run the attached EOL script. 2. Notice that the extended property is only properly printed when using Sequence{Sequence{1}}, and not when using Sequence{} and then add(1).
Created attachment 172555 Patch for reusing the wrappers in EolTypeWrapper
Created attachment 172556 Patch for avoiding unwrapping as much as possible in PointExecutor
Created attachment 172557 Sample EOL script which illustrates the problem

Thanks for reporting this. Please see comments below:
> * first try calling with wrapped values, and then try unwrapped values: > this fixes this problem, does not lose any of the available > API, and avoids the useless unwrapping and rewrapping that gets done > here. But I might be missing something here: is there a reason why > unwrapped values should be tried first, like now?
I'm sure I've changed the order numerous times in the past and eventually came to the conclusion that this was the best trade-off (though I don't remember exactly why).
> * change EolTypeWrapper so that when wrapping an object that was wrapped > before, the original wrapper will be returned. This uses more memory, > but it might solve the problem in a more general way.
I've also tried this but the memory footprint gets bigger and bigger as you're using Epsilon and eventually requires you to restart Eclipse :S
Object wrapping has always been a major source of trouble and I believe it makes sense to try to come up with a solution that does away with it altogether. I'm inclined not to fix this at the moment - assuming that's not a show-stopper for you - and address it in the context of a wider refactoring. Any thoughts on this?

(In reply to comment #4) > I'm sure I've changed the order numerous times in the past and eventually came > to the conclusion that this was the best trade-off (though I don't remember > exactly why).
That's what I thought as well: I guess there just isn't a definitive answer in this case. We can drop that patch, I guess.
> I've also tried this but the memory footprint gets bigger and bigger as you're > using Epsilon and eventually requires you to restart Eclipse :S
Ohh, I see. Adding it to the map means adding a strong reference to it, so we'll never garbage collect that object even if Epsilon does not need it anymore :-/.
We could use weak references to solve the problem, though. There is a WeakHashMap in the JDK which uses weak references and automatically garbage collects keys for which no strong references exist, so it's perfect for what we want. Here:
http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.4.2/docs/api/java/util/WeakHashMap.html
It implements the HashMap interface, so we only have to change a line in the actual code. I'll update the patch for the second approach with this, so you can try it out :-).
> Object wrapping has always been a major source of trouble and I believe it > makes sense to try to come up with a solution that does away with it > altogether. I'm inclined not to fix this at the moment - assuming that's not a > show-stopper for you - and address it in the context of a wider refactoring. > Any thoughts on this?
It *is* a show stopper for me, I'm afraid: one of my EOL scripts just won't work if I can't set extended properties on a nested sequence. However, I don't mind maintaining the patched version of Epsilon at my Git mirror [1] myself, so there is no hurry.
I think we could try WeakHashMap first and see if memory usage is kept low that way. If that doesn't work, then we could postpone the fix to a proper refactoring as you suggest. What do you think?
[1]: http://j.mp/aScYSS
Created attachment 172639 Patch for reusing the wrappers, using a WeakHashMap to save memory

For the record, trying to apply both fixes (reusing wrappers and trying methods with unwrapped values first) creates stability issues in EuGENia. It's an either/or situation.
Since we discarded the approach which tried wrapped values first, I have replaced the two original patches with a new patch that changes EolTypeWrapper to reuse the wrappers, but stores them in a WeakHashMap so (hopefully) entries are garbage collected when they are no longer needed.
I'll be testing this patch for a while and report any stability or performance problems. Is there any way I could stress test Epsilon automatically?

Thanks for investigating. I'm currently working on eliminating wrapping altogether: I've got rid of EolInteger, EolString, EolBoolean and EolReal in my working copy and am starting to attack EolCollection and its subclasses - so we may have a clean solution for this by the end of the day...
(In reply to comment #7) > For the record, trying to apply both fixes (reusing wrappers and trying methods > with unwrapped values first) creates stability issues in EuGENia. It's an > either/or situation. > > Since we discarded the approach which tried wrapped values first, I have > replaced the two original patches with a new patch that changes EolTypeWrapper > to reuse the wrappers, but stores them in a WeakHashMap so (hopefully) entries > are garbage collected when they are no longer needed. > > I'll be testing this patch for a while and report any stability or performance > problems. Is there any way I could stress test Epsilon automatically?
This has been fixed in the SVN and in the latest interim version. Could you please update and confirm that this has been resolved?
Created attachment 173623 Sample EOL script which shows a minor change in how EOL treats integers

(In reply to comment #9) > This has been fixed in the SVN and in the latest interim version. Could you > please update and confirm that this has been resolved?
It works great, thanks! However, I'd like to note that there has been a slight change in how Epsilon handles integers. I have attached a sample EOL script which worked before removing the wrappers, and that doesn't work anymore unless the type declaration of the first argument is removed or changed to Integer.
Basically, literal integers were implicitly converted into the EOL Real type before, but not any longer, so any operation which has a Real argument doesn't accept an integer anymore. I don't think it's a bug, but perhaps it should be noted in the release notes and/or the Epsilon book.
Thanks for letting us know! I think it's easier for everyone if we just fix this and restore the old behaviour. I'll roll out a new interim version shortly.

This should now be fixed in the SVN and the latest interim version available under http://download.eclipse.org/modeling/gmt/epsilon/interim/. Please let us know if you come across any other unexpected changes. Many thanks for your help!!
Fixed in 0.9.0.

bug.short_desc: [EOL] Equals sign for performing assignment

long_desc.thetext: Currently, EOL's syntax stipulates that = should be used to test equality, and := should be used for assignment. However, this frequently leads to problems caused by attempting to use = for assignment. When = is used where an assignment can appear, EOL should issue a warning or re-write the equality to an assignment.

Rewriting logic has been added to StatementBlockExecutor. Now, when a statement begins with a test for equality sign, it is rewritten such it begins with an assignment. For example:
a = 1 + 1;
is rewritten to:
a := 1 + 1;
and a evaluates to 2.
EOL's parser has also been changed to make the equality operator right-associative. For example:
a = 1 = 1
is parsed as:
a = (1 = 1)
and a evaluates to true.
This enhancement will appear in version 0.8.5.
Re-opening bug for consistency. Bug will be closed when 0.8.5 is released.
Fixed in 0.8.5
Changed status to CLOSED

I've added an acceptance test to cover this behaviour, and changed EglPreprocessorModule and EglRuntimeException to report EolInteralExceptions.
I've checked this into SVN, so assigning to Dimitris for build integration. Thanks!

bug.short_desc: [EGL] Importing a non-existent file does not produce an error

long_desc.thetext:
An EGL template that imports a non-existent file does not report any parse problems. In the development tools, no problem markers are shown.
The following template can be used to reproduce the problem:
[%import 'NonExistent.egl'; %]
The EGL editor reports no problems for the above template.

This is a regression, introduced by the recent EGL refactorings. EglPreprocessorModule returned a defensive copy of ParseProblems, meaning that all calls to getParseProblems().add() would not modify the underlying collection.
I've changed EglPreprocessorModule to return a reference to the underlying collection, which fixes this issue.
Fix and regression test checked into SVN. Assigning to Dimitris for build integration - thanks!
Fixed in the latest interim version.
Fixed in 0.9.0.

bug.short_desc: [EGL] Operations should have access to out and dynamic sections

long_desc.thetext:
out is currently a local variable, it should be a global. However, making it a global would mean that subtemplates would access the same outputbuffer as their parent, and this is undesirable. Instead, we need a mechanism for indicating that a variable has global scope in the current template, and is inaccessible from subtemplates.
Chatting with Antonio, it seems he has a similar problem for data bindings in EUnit. We need to discuss this and see if there is a common solution.
Fixing this will cause the error message added for #313119 to be redundant, and that logic should be removed.

Fixing this will make it less clear when to annotate an operation with @template. The differences should be investigated:
Do we need to make @template and normal operations exactly the same? If so, do we need to deprecate @template? Do we need to make @template and normal operation more different in some way?
Either way, we should also update the EGL documentation.

(In reply to comment #1) > out is currently a local variable, it should be a global. However, making it a > global would mean that subtemplates would access the same outputbuffer as their > parent, and this is undesirable. Instead, we need a mechanism for indicating > that a variable has global scope in the current template, and is inaccessible > from subtemplates. > > Chatting with Antonio, it seems he has a similar problem for data bindings in > EUnit. We need to discuss this and see if there is a common solution.
For now, I've fixed this by shuffling the global frame before and after executing a template. We've opened #347367 and will investigate a more general solution in the future.

(In reply to comment #2) > Fixing this will cause the error message added for #313119 to be redundant, and > that logic should be removed.
I've removed this check as part of the fix.

(In reply to comment #3) > Fixing this will make it less clear when to annotate an operation with > @template. The differences should be investigated: > > Do we need to make @template and normal operations exactly the same? If so, do > we need to deprecate @template? > Do we need to make @template and normal operation more different in some way? > > Either way, we should also update the EGL documentation.
I've opened #347370 to cover this investigation and update to the documentation.
Fix checked into SVN. Assigning to Dimitris for build integration, thanks!
This is fixed in SVN, and will appear in the next interim/stable builds.
Fixed in 0.9.1

bug.short_desc: [Eugenia] Issue generating .gmf* files when a project does not live in the eclipse workspace

long_desc.thetext:
Eugenia has a problem with projects that are *not* located in (or "under") the eclipse workspace, but somewhere else in the filesystem. If one issues the .ecore-file => right-click => Eugenia => "Generate GMF tool, map and graph models"-command in such projects, then "nothing" happens. If the project lives in the workspace everything works fine.
I reported this in the newsgroup and Dimitris Kolovos [dskolovos@gmail.com] was able to reproduce and verify the issue. His tentative analysis:
------- ... For some reason, I assumed that projects could only be located in the workspace, but apparently this doesn't hold. There are a few places in Epsilon where this assumption is used in order to produce absolute paths from relative ones so we'll need to find and fix them, and also test for regressions. ... -------
Regards, Michael
Fixed in 0.8.4
Changed status to CLOSED

bug.short_desc: Consider making EolReal use double as storage instead of float

long_desc.thetext: Floats lack precision and there isn't a compelling performance or efficiency argument for using them instead of doubles. I also think most ecore models represent floating point values as doubles.
This seems fairly reasonable indeed. I'll run a few tests to see if this introduces any regressions.

I am aware real is mapped to float in OCL, but I also think there are OCL implementations which use doubles. I think loss of precision is very unfortunate.
However, using double also means that EolReal can represent values outside of EolIntegers range. How could one represent long integer in OCL ? Living in 64-bit world of today, OCL default type mappings seem rather limiting.

I originally used float because it's more predictable (see http://firstclassthoughts.co.uk/java/traps/java_double_traps.html for counterexamples). Thinking about this again, I'm more inclined to add a Double type rather than to change the Real one. This would also mean that we'll need to change the grammar so that it can distinguish between floats and doubles (e.g. 0.04f and 0.04d) like Java does. Any thoughts on this?

I think adding doubles in addition to floats is a much larger change to OCL type system, than changing real to double.
To me, the right solution would be to make EolReal and EolInteger representation-agnostic. EolReal could store BigDecimals, floats and doubles, and could use all these representations for arithmetic operations and setting object properties. EolInteger could do the same for integers, longs and larger numbers. This would keep number coercion away from type system and avoid proliferation of native types.
... forgot to mention that all .println() calls above print "true"
Fixed in 0.8.5
Changed status to CLOSED

here is a path again. Trick is to display package list directly without resolution of Epackage.Descriptors into Epackage instances. BTW the Registered package view has also this isssue (do not support EPackage.Descriptor)

bug.short_desc: EOL Editor Supported Comments

long_desc.thetext:
When editing epsilon languages the editor fails to correctly recognize the end of multiline comments when using the /* ... */ or the -* ... *- style. This happens either with new comments or when editing existing ones. If the file is closed and reopened the editor recognizes the comment ends correctly.
The bug is detected because after the comment is closed the rest of the text in the file remains colored as comments.
Thanks for your report! I'll have a look today at the bug.

This is a follow up to this thread in the forum:
http://www.eclipse.org/forums/index.php/t/209207/
I think I have fixed the problem in SVN r1422. The fix itself is trivial, but finding the part that required fixing took a while.
The partition scanner we use to divide the program into comment and non-comment sections has two JFace MultiLineRules for the -* *- and /* */ comments. Normally, these rules look for their start delimiter and then for their end delimiter. In this case, the rules do not conflict, as they start with different characters.
However, there's one case in which PatternRule#doEvaluate skips looking for the start sequence: when "resuming" the partition scanning. This happens when we insert a newline inside a comment, for example. PatternRule sees the * in *- and mistakes it for the * in */. Since breakOnEOF is set to true for that rule, it plows through the rest of the file and accepts EOF as an end sequence.
I have fixed this bug by setting breakOnEOF to false, so it will properly reject the */ rule and go to the *- rule.
Fixed in 0.9.1

bug.short_desc: EOLString operation to check if it can be parsed as an EOLInteger

long_desc.thetext:
Hi there,
Would it be possible to add an operation to EOLString that complements the existing asInteger() operation. This new operation will determine whether the EOLString object can successfully be parsed as an EOLInteger?
e.g., with a signature as follows (you choose a name as appropriate though):
public EOLBoolean isInteger()
And this returns true if and only if the EOLString is of the form, [0-9]+ (in terms of regular expressions).
The need for this is because currently asInteger() currently returns 0 (zero) if the EOLString cannot be parsed as an integer, which may give you unexpected results in an EOL program.
See discussion in the Epsilon forum: http://www.eclipse.org/newsportal/article.php?id=510&group=eclipse.epsilon#510
Thanks!

I'm interested in this enhancement too. It would allow us to simplify a couple of EOL operations used in the Epsilon HUTN implementation.
For my own reference, these are:
AntlrAst2Intermediate.etl#inferType ValidateConfigurationModel.evl#isCompatibleWith
Added isInteger() and isReal() operations to EolString and committed to the SVN. The fix will appear in 0.8.7.

It > comes down to this. > > > rule exampleTrafo > transform d : Source!Domain > to d : Target!Domain{ > > var choice = "bigDecision"; > > switch(choice){ > case "bigDecision" : var temp = createSomething(); > if(not temp.isDefined()) > "ohh boy".println(); > } > } > > operation createSomething() : Target!Element1{ > var returnValue = new Target!Element1; > if(returnValue.isDefined()) > "I'm ready to go".println(); > return returnValue; > } > > > I would expect to get a plain "I'm ready to go" , unfortunately I get > the following output: > > Buildfile: /Users/henning/Documents/workspaces/diplom/my.example/launch > .xml > > loadModels: > > main: > [epsilon.etl - exampleTrafo.etl] I'm ready to go > [epsilon.etl - exampleTrafo.etl] ohh boy > BUILD SUCCESSFUL > Total time: 246 milliseconds > > Is this behavior intended? > > Best regards, > > Henning

bug.short_desc: Better support for real literals

long_desc.thetext:
As reported by Konrad Schwarz in #333740, EOL does not support exponentes in real literals. I've had a look at the grammar and EOL is rather more restrictive than Java for real numbers.
I think we should support these formats:
- 4.2 (with '.', already accepted) - 4d or 4f (only with 'd' or 'f', currently we would need to use '4.0d') - 4e1, 4e+1, 4e-1 (not accepted now) - 4e1d (not accepted now) - 4.0e1d (not accepted now)
We should fix this before writing the section on literals mentioned in #333740, so we don't have to go back, fix it and revise the documentation.
I'll work on this now, seeing that we'll have to generate all parsers for the Map literals anyway.

I have committed the required code to SVN. While I was fixing this bug, I added UNIX launch configurations to generate the ANTLR parsers for the E*L languages and fixed some minor issues in the EOL and Flock ANTLR launch configurations.
EUnit should also provide more information when finding parsing errors in the EOL test cases.
Fixed in 0.9.1

bug.short_desc: Operation return types are not checked

long_desc.thetext: *** Bug 338379 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

I have fixed this bug in SVN r1447. While fixing this bug, I found a typo in an EVL script inside HUTN.
Return types are cached inside EolOperations, and clearing the cache also cleans the cached return type. This is important in EUnit, as we will be reusing the same EolModule over several sets of models. If we didn't clear the cached return type between tests, the return type could refer to a model that is no longer in memory. This issue was detected in one of the Eugenia regression tests, and is now fixed.

bug.short_desc: EVL / GMF integration does not refresh diagram editor after applying quick fix

long_desc.thetext:
From newsgroup post by Antonio García Domínguez (http://www.eclipse.org/forums/index.php?t=msg&th=152126&start=0&S=bfbb2f5cf3d5ad09808fb3a2ab1d6313):
I'm using Galileo in Linux (build ID I20090611-1540). I'm using the modeling distribution which includes the incubating components, and the latest Epsilon interim release.
The model involved is basically a control flow graph, and I'm making sure that there are no edges whose source and target point to the same node. The EVL script is like this:
context ActivityEdge { constraint NoCycles { check : self.source <> self.target message : 'Source and target of an edge must not be the same' fix { title : 'Remove link from model' do { delete self; } } } }
I have some simple custom graphical components and the edge connects two components which are inside of a compartment (the edge itself is not).
The steps to reproduce the problem are as follows:
1. Define a new graph in the form of start -> do something -> finish. 2. Add a cycle, violating the above constraint. 3. Use Edit -> Validate. The error for the above constraint appears, with the correct marker over the edge. 4. Right click on the error in the Problems view, use Quick Fix, use "Remove link from model".
Here is the problem:
5. The error message and the marker disappear, but not the edge.
The rest of the errors remain, but I suppose this is on purpose. IIRC, custom code is needed to run validation every time the file is saved. After that, there are several possibilities, which all work as expected:
6a. Close without saving, and then reopen. As expected, the edge remains both in the diagram and the model. 6b. Save, then close, and then reopen. As expected, the edge has disappeared from both the diagram and the model. 6c. Refresh with F5. The diagram is properly updated, and when saved, the model is updated as well.

I've been able to recreate this bug. As discussed here: http://dev.eclipse.org/newslists/news.eclipse.modeling.gmf/msg04508.html
The EMF resource must be saved before the GMF editor will automatically refresh.
In EvlMarkerResolution, I've added a call to eResource().save() on the model element being fixed. For now, no save options are passed to save. Once we have some usage date, it may be necessary to specify some options.

Committed to SVN.
Reassigning to Dimitrios for build integration. Thanks :-)

Oddly enough, it doesn't always refresh yet with the latest SVN release. I still have to use F5 sometimes. There has been one time when Eclipse asked me if I wanted to refresh the editor to the latest version of the contents of the diagram file, but I haven't been able to reproduce it.

I revisited this bug this morning.
On many occasions, my GMF diagram was consistent with my EMF model after applying a quick fix. A couple of times, however, the diagram was not updated to reflect the changes applied by the quick fix to the model, the diagram editor did not mark the diagram as dirty (having unsaved changes), yet the model was updated.
I can't reliably recreate this issue, and as such I'm not sure how best to proceed.

Replacing eResource().save() with eResource().setModified(true) seems to be working equally well. I'm inclined to replace the former with the latter as saving without being asked to might seem a bit strange to the eyes of users. Any thoughts on this?
(In reply to comment #1) > I've been able to recreate this bug. As discussed here: > http://dev.eclipse.org/newslists/news.eclipse.modeling.gmf/msg04508.html > > The EMF resource must be saved before the GMF editor will automatically > refresh. > > In EvlMarkerResolution, I've added a call to eResource().save() on the model > element being fixed. For now, no save options are passed to save. Once we have > some usage date, it may be necessary to specify some options. >

(In reply to comment #5) > Replacing eResource().save() with eResource().setModified(true) seems to be > working equally well. I'm inclined to replace the former with the latter as > saving without being asked to might seem a bit strange to the eyes of users. > Any thoughts on this?
setModified(true) to seems to work just as well as save() for me. I agree that saving without being asked is likely to seem strange to users.
Fixed in 0.8.7
Changed status to CLOSED

bug.short_desc: [EOL] Unqualified types can be ambiguous

long_desc.thetext:
When executing an EOL program on a model repository containing more than one model, EOL prefers to resolve unqualified types in the first model.
For example, suppose we have two models First and Second, both conforming to a metamodel that defines a Foo class. Executing "new Foo" will create a Foo in the First model. This is potentially dangerous, as it might not be what users expect.
I think it's better to throw an error in this case, and encourage users to use the fully qualified syntax.

I think this precedes EUnit and was actually intentional so that the first model in the configuration could be treated as "primary". Let's have a chat about this in the next telecon so that I can explain the rationale behind this and perhaps we can come up with a better solution.

"svn blame" says I only added the two comment lines there to make sure anyone touching that code had EUnit in mind. That did work, didn't it? :-D
I think Dimitris introduced that code in 11th September 2008 (revision 8). Perhaps you should ask him before reverting that change.
In any case, even we change it, it shouldn't be that big of an issue. In fact, it should simplify EUnit quite a bit. Right now, we have to treat the first model differently from the rest, because of this "default model" concept.
We should also think about breaking existing EOL scripts. I think we should throw a warning, instead of an error. We could switch to an error a few releases down the road.

(In reply to comment #4) > "svn blame" says I only added the two comment lines there to make sure anyone > touching that code had EUnit in mind. That did work, didn't it? :-D > > I think Dimitris introduced that code in 11th September 2008 (revision 8). > Perhaps you should ask him before reverting that change. > > In any case, even we change it, it shouldn't be that big of an issue. In fact, > it should simplify EUnit quite a bit. Right now, we have to treat the first > model differently from the rest, because of this "default model" concept. > > We should also think about breaking existing EOL scripts. I think we should > throw a warning, instead of an error. We could switch to an error a few > releases down the road.
D'oh! I misinterpreted the comment, sorry Antonio. I thought this was a recent change for EUnit, rather than a long-standing feature of EOL!
I agree with Antonio, we should avoid making changes that will break existing EOL scripts: a warning would be a good idea, if the type is ambiguous. Let's discuss this together on Thursday.

We discussed this in person today. In summary...
Currently: - EOL permits unqualified types when there is only one model in the repository. - Consequently, users have (in the past) written sets of EOL operations (with unqualified types) that they wish to import into an Epsilon program that uses more than one model (e.g. a transformation). Therefore, EOL *always* resolves unqualified types in the first model in a repository.
This is perhaps unpredictable behaviour from a user's perspective. This behaviour is particularly problematic in Flock because the Original and Migrated models often conform to metamodels that share a lot of types.
We decided that the minimum we need to do is issue a warning when an unqualified reference is used for a type that is defined by more than model in the repository. This bug will cover that change.
We will also investigate a better mechanism for importing EOL operations into other programs (e.g. transformations).

(In reply to comment #6) > We decided that the minimum we need to do is issue a warning when an > unqualified reference is used for a type that is defined by more than model in > the repository. This bug will cover that change.
I've checked in to SVN a fix that issues warnings when ambiguous types are used.
Fixed in 0.9.1

bug.short_desc: AbstractModule.parse should throw exception on any problem

bug.short_desc: Regression: Handling of target in EglTask broken

Build Identifier: M20080911-1700

java.lang.ClassCastException: java.lang.String cannot be cast to org.eclipse.epsilon.egl.EglFileGeneratingTemplate at org.eclipse.epsilon.workflow.tasks.EglTask.examine(EglTask.java:32) at org.eclipse.epsilon.workflow.tasks.ExecutableModuleTask.executeImpl(ExecutableModuleTask.java:118) at org.eclipse.epsilon.workflow.tasks.EpsilonTask.execute(EpsilonTask.java:41) at org.apache.tools.ant.UnknownElement.execute(UnknownElement.java:288) ...
This does not happen when no target attribute is given and the template determines target file names itself.

bug.short_desc: [Eugenia] Problems in the generated editor. The Folder item (in the tutorial) is not generated correctly

I followed the tutorial from http://www.eclipse.org/gmt/epsilon/doc/articles/eugenia-gmf-tutorial/ and the corresponding screencast from http://www.eclipse.org/gmt/epsilon/cinema/Eugenia.htm.
I have had problems with the annotations which do not have properties, so I solved the problems creating the foo property, as it is written in the tutorial(I've read in a previous post that this problem is due to the emfatic version), so I have written the annotations @gmf(foo="bar"), and @gmf.diagram(foo="bar"), and @gmf.compartment(foo="bar").

bug.short_desc: Missing SVG image support in Eugenia

long_desc.thetext:
It should be possible to specify a SVG image path in the 'gmf.node' (Ecore) annotation. A possible solution would be to add an 'svg-image' attribute to the 'gmf.node' annotation that must contain the fully qualified name of a SVG image. Than the editor shall use the SVG image instead of the Draw2d figure. The GMF framework support SVG images.
Thank you for Eugenia!

Eugenia currently supports custom figures which you can use to add SVG nodes to your editor (i.e. @gmf.node(figure="org.mypackage.MySVGFigure")). I'm not aware of a way to specify in the .gmfgraph model that the figure of a node is an SVG image. If this is possible, could you please attach a sample .gmfgraph model that shows how to do this?

I have example, but it seems there is a new feautre in GMF where you can specify the SVG Figure directly in the gmf graph model. Have a look at http://wiki.eclipse.org/GMFGraph_Hints#SVG . Up to now it was only possible by modifing the generated source code, like it is described in http://wiki.eclipse.org/index.php/GMF_Tutorial_BPMN#Custom_Figures_.28SVG.29 .
When I am back from vacation maybe I can try it by myself and can create an example gmfgraph model with an SVG figure.
This looks promising. Looking forward to your concrete example.
This is now possible using the extension discussed in http://epsilonlabs.wiki.sourceforge.net/EuGENia+Customization. Closing as fixed in 0.8.6 as per bug #265285.
Changed status to CLOSED

bug.short_desc: Access to arbitrary metamodels in EVL

long_desc.thetext:
There's a need to access other metamodels in .evl files than the one specified by the namespaceURI in appropriate constraintsBinding (child of org.eclipse.epsilon.evl.emf.validation extension point).
Specifically, such feature is desirable if the metamodel is split into several .ecore files. For example:
<CoreMM.ecore> CorePackage : EPackage CoreSubPackage : EPackage CoreClass : EClass (contains ClassX elements) ClassX : EClass (contains references to ClassY) ClassY : EClass (abstract)
<ChildMM.ecore> ChildPackage : EPackage ChildSubPackage : EPackage ChildOfY : EClass -> ClassY
Developed GMF editor for CoreClass can draw diagram nodes for ClassX and ChildOfY meta-elements. I've created a .evl constraint binded to CoreSubPackage namespaceURI:
context ClassX {...}
Now I'd like to implement a quick-fix in this constraint which would create a ChildOfY node in my diagram and add a reference to it into the validated ClassX if needed. But at the moment there's no way I can get to ChildOfY EClass to create its instance.

Added an addMetamodelUri(String uri) method to EmfModel which allows adding namespace uris at runtime. The enhancement has been committed to the SVN, is available in the interim version 0.8.5.200905011421 and will appear in 0.8.6.
Fixed in 0.8.6.
Changed status to CLOSED

bug.short_desc: [EGL] Use of static sections in operations should cause better error message

[%=main()%] [% operation main() {%] foo [%}%]

Normal operations cannot use static sections; an @template operation should be used for this purpose. The error message reveals an implementation detail and does not make obvious the root cause of the problem.

I've caught the TypeNotFound exception, and raised instead the new EglUnallocatedOutputBufferException. The new error message is:
The operation 'main' uses a static section but has not been annotated with @template.

bug.short_desc: [Eugenia] Wishlist (part 3) of annotations that should make it from the .emf file to the .genmodel, or .gmfgen file, resp.

Additonal options for Nodes: container: child alignments
Additonal options for Nodes => Figures: corner diameter for Rounded Rectangle

To speed things up it would be really helpful if you could do a bit of investigation and provide some hints as to what one needs to do in the .gmfxxx models in order e.g. to set the grid on/off etc. (I'm afraid that a some of these options are not controlled by the .gmfxxx models at all)

bug.short_desc: "Resource does not exist" with epsilon.emf.register and permanently=true

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 144704 Patch which seems to fix the problem
Build ID: 20090619-0625
Steps To Reproduce: Add a line like this to an Ant buildfile:
<epsilon.emf.register file="${ecore.location}" permanently="true"/>
On my Linux box, it reports that the resource "platform:/resource/absolute/path/to/my/file" does not exist.
More information: Using this instead worked, so I assumed that it was something in the way the permanently attribute (false by default, if I'm not mistaken) was interpreted:
<epsilon.emf.register file="${ecore.location}"/>
I looked at the code in o.e.e.workflow.tasks.emf.RegisterTask and it appeared that though EmfUtil#register was OK with getting a file URI, EmfRegistryManager#addMetamodel expected a path relative to the workspace location. However, it was getting the absolute path to the file:
EmfRegistryManager.getInstance().addMetamodel(file.getAbsolutePath());
I've attached a patch which modifies RegisterTask so it tries to first convert the absolute file path to a workspace relative path, and then hands it to EmfRegistryManager#addMetaModel. It does work, but it could be cleaner, I guess :-D.
Many thanks for reporting this. I've applied the patch and committed to the SVN. The fix will appear in 0.8.7
Fixed in 0.8.7
Changed status to CLOSED

bug.short_desc: ANT doesn't seem to pick up Epsilon tasks when run in VM different from Eclipse VM

long_desc.thetext:
I've written a simple ANT workflow that uses some of the Epsilon tasks. The ANT editor in Eclipse finds the tasks and happily offers them and their parameters to me as part of its autocompletion. So, somehow, they seem to be registered correctly. However, once I trigger the build script using Run As/Ant Build, the build fails and ANT complains about not finding the task definitions. Here's what it says:
...\build.xml:12: Problem: failed to create task or type epsilon.emf.loadModel Cause: The name is undefined.
I am using Epsilon from SVN, that is, I have one Eclipse instance in which I have some of the Epsilon projects open (...workflow among them) and from this start a second Eclipse instance which contains my actual workflow. If I look at the launch configuration for my ANT script, it actually doesn't refer to the workflow.jar file created as part of the workflow project. Adding this manually does not help either. Checking the global Ant preferences and, in particular, the 'Runtime' category, I find that workflow.jar is there allright and all the Epsilon tasks are listed as well.
ANT works OK when I tell it to run in the same VM as the IDE (which unfortunately is not the default). But it does not work when running in a separate VM.
Created attachment 139994 plugin.xml with fixed eclipseRuntime attributes

It seems, when you extend the org.eclipse.ant.core.extraClasspathEntries extension point and do not specify a value for the eclipseRuntime property for some classpath entry, this defaults to true restricting the classpath entry to the cases where ANT is run in the same VM as Eclipse. There is a similar attribute for each task made available through the antTasks extension point.
The attached plugin.xml fixes this and the tasks are now available. However, there is another issue:
C:\workspaces\symmetric_ao_cg\SymmetricAOCGTest\workflow\build.xml:12: Type epsilon.emf.loadModel: A class needed by class class org.eclipse.epsilon.workflow.tasks.emf.LoadModel cannot be found: org/eclipse/epsilon/eol/exceptions/models/EolModelLoadingException

Thanks for investigating. It seems that to be able to run the tasks in a new VM, all the classes they use should be visible to the VM as well. A simple
<project default="main"> <target name="main"> <epsilon.eol> 'Hello world'.println(); </epsilon.eol> </target> </project>
generates a similar
E:\Projects\Eclipse\3.4\EMFIndexing\ConcordanceDemo\build.xml:3: Type epsilon.eol: A class needed by class class org.eclipse.epsilon.workflow.tasks.EolTask cannot be found: org/eclipse/epsilon/eol/models/IModel
exception. So there seem to be two options: bundle everything in the the org.eclipse.epsilon.workflow.jar or live with the "Run in the same VM" option. The prior may easily explode in size as I suspect we'll also need to bundle parts of EMF, the ANTLR runtime etc, but would be useful if someone needs to run Epsilon in ANT without Eclipse.

I'm afraid it is actually a bit worse even. I am currently experimenting with a separate plugin project defining a few additional tasks that extend some basic Epsilon tasks. I'm generating a similar jar file for these tasks, but cannot get them to run because ANT doesn't manage to find the standard Epsilon tasks they depend on. And, this is true even when running ANT in the same VM as Eclipse...
I'm currently trying to figure out if I can set the Class-Path header in my MANIFEST file appropriately, but have difficulty divining what to let it point to. The relative positions of the basic Epsilon plugins and my plugins could be so wonderfully different that I'm not entirely sure what to set the classpath to. I think, I'll give up for today.
Strange thing is, though, that for workflow.jar it seems to find the other classes that this depends on without any problems (e.g., the basic EOL classes...)
I'm looking into this now, alas with no apparent success so far.

I've tried several things but can't seem to be able to make it work... I suspect we should send a message to the eclipse.platform (I think) newsgroup since the issue of extending existing ANT tasks is more general...

Deleting the . library in the Runtime Information of the Build tab in MANIFEST.MF in the extension plugin (and exporting the task packages in the org.eclipse.epsilon.workflow plugin) did the trick.
I've committed the changes to the org.eclipse.epsilon.workflow plugin and shared the example project that provides an extension to the epsilon.eol task (epsilon.eol.ext) under https://dev.eclipse.org/svnroot/modeling/org.eclipse.gmt.epsilon/trunk/examples/org.eclipse.epsilon.workflow.extension.example
Fixed in Epsilon 0.8.8
Changed status to CLOSED

bug.short_desc: [EMC] EmfModel#load(StringProperties, String) and clients should make same assumptions about model/metamodel locations

long_desc.thetext:
There are several clients of EmfModel#load(StringProperties, String), such as EmfModelConfigurationDialog and LoadModelTask. The clients pass different types of location for models and metamodels, such as fully-qualified URIs (e.g. starting with "file://" or "platform:/resource"), platform resource relative paths (e.g. "/MyProject/my.model") and absolute system paths (e.g. "/tmp/my.model" or "C:\my.model"). In EmfModel#load(StringProperties, String), we attempt to infer the most appropriate type of location from the string passed by the client. In particular, we've tried to infer whether an unqualified location should be interpreted as a platform resource URI or as a file URI.
We've tried lots of tricks in the past, such as assuming that when basePath is null, the client is indicating that the path should be interpreted as a file URI. However, we've often forgotten to fix all of the clients of EmfModel#load(StringProperties, String) when changing the assumptions made by EmfModel. This has led to regressions, such as #280056 and #285559
To try to avoid these issues in the future, we can: (1) change EmfModel such that its clients provide a fully-qualified URI (2) add regression tests for EmfModel#load(StringProperties, String) (3) document the new protocol for using EmfModel#load(StringProperties, String)

The following clients use EmfModel#load(StringProperties, String):
- EugeniaActionDelegate - AbstractECoreModelAction - NewEmfModelWizard - LoadModel - LoadModelTask* - EclipseContextManager*
The starred clients retrieve property keys from data stored by the Epsilon user, such as in an Eclipse launch configuration or in an ANT build file. In order not to break existing user data, we must continue to support the existing loading protocol, which can infer a fully qualified URI when an unqualified URI is supplied.

(In reply to comment #1) > The following clients use EmfModel#load(StringProperties, String):
There is also:
- ModelManager (EglServlet)
Accidentally closed bug.

For the clients that construct StringProperties from user data (EclipseContextManager and LoadModelTask), we will need to support the old properties (PROPERTY_MODEL_FILE and PROPERTY_METAMODEL_FILE). To this end, I have:
- Updated EmfModelConfigurationDialogue to ensure that new launch configurations use the new properties. - Introduced EmfModel.PropertyMigrator, which inspects an instance of StringProperties, and migrates any legacy properties to their new equivalents.
I've not changed LoadModelTask which now relies on EmfModel.PropertyMigrator for executing loadModel ANT statements that use the legacy properties. Migrating the legacy properties in LoadModelTask would have involved coupling LoadModelTask to EmfModel, which did not seem sensible as LoadModelTask does not currently need to know which implementation of IModel it is instantiating.

A quick summary of the most important changes:
- EmfModel's PROPERTY_MODEL_FILE and PROPERTY_METAMODEL_FILE have been deprecated in favour of PROPERTY_MODEL_URI and PROPERTY_FILE_BASED_METAMODEL_URI - EmfModel.PropertyMigrator has been introduced so that uses of the deprecated properties will continue to be supported - All of our code that uses EmfModel#load(StringProperties, String) has been updated to use the new rather than the old properties. EmfModelConfigurationDialogue continues to rely on the deprecated properties so as to support legacy launch configurations.
I've commited the first round of changes, described in all of the comments above, to SVN.

Louis, you probably solved my older bug#329311 ... I will test your patch and report result.
Thanks.

(In reply to comment #8) > Louis, you probably solved my older bug#329311 ... I will test your patch and > report result. > > Thanks.
Hi Ivo. Great -- that's a happy coincidence. Do let me know if this patch fixes bug#329311 and I'll mark it as a duplicate.

I've tested the changes on Windows and Mac OS, and there seem to be no regressions.
I also committed a small patch to ensure that EmfModel does not migrate legacy properties that are paired with the empty string. Some existing launch configurations will use pair a legacy property with the empty string because the user has "cleared" a text box that previously contained a value.
I think we're done with this for now. Assigning to Dimitris for build integration.
This is fixed in SVN, and will make it into the next interim/stable builds.
Fixed in 0.9.1

bug.short_desc: [EGL] Deprecate store in favour of generate

long_desc.thetext:
EglFileGeneratingTemplate currently provides three ways to write a file to disk:
generate(path): if path exists, merges the generated text into the path respecting protected regions else, writes a new file at path containing the generated text
store(path), store(path, false): if path exists, print a warning message else, writes a new file at path containing the generated text
store(path, true): if path exists, writes a new file at path containing the generated text (potentially overwriting protected regions) else, writes a new file at path containing the generated text
Having investigated our acceptance tests and EGLDoc, I see no reason to keep the last two. Consequently, I am proposing that store/1 and store/2 be deprecated.
Dimitris - do you have any thoughts on this?

I've tidied up and integrated Stefan's patch. The name issue has been resolved, and deprecation warnings are now printed in the Epsilon console for store/1, store/2. I've also updated the Epsilon book and examples.

bug.short_desc: Wizard menu becomes static in one diagram when a second diagram's wizard menu is used

long_desc.thetext:
I have found what I think is a bug inside the epsilon ewl.emf plugin. The issue is that the wizard menu becomes an orphan and is no longer maintained by the code. It simply stays in the same state till the diagram is closed and reopened. This can be reproduced very easily, 1) create a new diagram with model 2) add entities to the diagram 3) right click on any of the entities and go to the wizard menu so a title is produced and displayed (do not need to execute wizard) 4) save diagram and initialize a new diagram from the same model 5) right click on any entity in the new diagram and go to the wizard menu so a title is displayed (do not need to execute wizard) 6) go back to first diagram and right click on an entity to view a wizard that is available for it
The title that is displayed in the wizard should not change now regardless of the entity that is selected in the first diagram editor. Through debugging I see that AbstractContributeWizardsAction is only created once globally, it is not created per diagram. The method getMenu(Menu parent) is called for the first time the wizard menu is accessed per diagram. Each time it is called it overwrites the menu for the previous diagram resulting in the static wizard that is seen in the first diagram editor.
Is this really a critical bug; i.e. does it prevent you from doing your work or is it just a nuisance? I'm asking so that I can prioritize it accordingly in my todo list.

The wizards are a feature that helps us tremendously when diagramming. At times we do work with more than one diagram at a time and this is where the issue comes up. I have patched the plugin jar to fix this issue temporarily. Simply making the menu created once and not repeatedly for every diagram that is opened. This fix does work for the meantime but I am unaware if this is how you thought it should be (global or per diagram). If to be global the fix takes no more than a minute to do, if per diagram I'm not positive on how difficult that would be. For now I am fine with my patched jar, and the priority could be lowered if necessary.
Thanks for your prompt reply! Could you please attach the patch so that I can have a look into it?
This makes sense. I've committed the change to AbstractContributeWizardsAction in the SVN and will roll out a new interim version shortly. The fix will appear in 0.8.7. Thanks for your help!
your welcome, Thank you.
