bug.short_desc: [Eugenia] Wishlist (part 1) of annotations that should make it from the .emf file to the .genmodel, or .gmfgen file, resp.

long_desc.thetext:
From the newsgroup: --------------- in news:gne8qc$j01$1@build.eclipse.org mm@zurich.ibm.com wrote: --------------- I guess there is no way to include certain gmfgen options already in the .emf file, is there? I would find it cool, if one could set certain flags like the "Same file for diagram and model"-option or the file extension already in the .emf file.
Spinning this further: what would really be cool, would be a possibility to include arbitrary .gmftool / .gmfgraph (e.g. icon file names) / .gmfmap and - most importantly - .gmfgen flags (like the ones mentioned) already in the .emf file and hence - by means of annotations - also in the .ecore file.
I have no idea, whether that is possible but I think it would be a great feature for Eugenia and EMF!
Michael ---------------
--------------- in news:gne9k2$dc0$3@build.eclipse.org dskolovos@gmail.com responded: --------------- Hi Michael,
There is no straightforward way to do this yet I'm afraid for custom annotations. However, we are planning to provide support for user-defined transformations that extend the functionality of the default ones so that people can add and exploit custom annotations.
This said, there appear to be some specific options such as the ones you mentioned that subsequent versions of Eugenia could support out-of-the-box.
Could you please write down a list of such annotations that you'd like to see in future versions of EuGENia (annotations in the metamodel + how they should be reflected in the generated models). If you could also raise an enhancement request in the bugzilla, that'd be great!
Cheers, Dimitrios ---------------
Here's the first half of my wishlist:
@ .genmodel flags: ? Copyright ? Language
I guess the best location for this would be if this were attributes of the top-most @gmf annotation, i.e.: @gmf(..., copyright="foo-bar", language="en_US ", ...)
Result in .genmodel file: <?xml ... > <genmodel:GenModel ... copyrightFields="true" copyrightText="foo bar" language="en_US"> ... </ ...>
@ .gmfgen flags: ! Same file for diagram and model ! Model file extension ( \ only one of these if) ! Diagram file extension ( / the above is true) ! Units ? Inclusion of default tools (Zoom, Note, ...) - is this controllable via .gmfgen flags?
Again , the best location for the annotation would probably as attributes of the top-most @gmf annotation, i.e.: @gmf(..., sameFileForDiagamAndModel="true", modelExtension="foo", diagramFileExtension="bar", units="centimeters", ...)
Result in .gmfgen file: <?xml ... > <gmfgen:GenEditorGenerator ... sameFileForDiagramAndModel="true" diagramFileExtension="foo" domainFileExtension="bar"> <diagram ... units="centimeters"... </ ...> ... </ ...>
Michael

What remains to be fixed in the SVN:
@ .genmodel flags: ? Copyright ? Language
and
? Inclusion of default tools (Zoom, Note, ...) - is this controllable via .gmfgen flags?
Regarding the genmodel flags, this would mean that an additional step must be added to EuGENia which modifies the .genmodel (the current version doesn't need to touch this model). Also, I imagine that including a multi-line copyright notice in the .emf will look ugly. Therefore, I'm more inclined to go for another solution: instead of embedding the copyright, the user will have to put it in a text file with a predefined name (e.g. copyright.txt) next to the .ecore. If Eugenia finds such a file, it will put its contents in the copyrightText field of both the .genmodel and the .gmfgen. Any obvious defects in this solution?
Regarding the default tools (Zoom, Note etc.), I'm not sure either ;) Could you please check if/how this is done manually so that we can then automate it?

Support for copyright implemented and committed to the SVN (see section "Adding Copyright" in http://epsilonlabs.wiki.sourceforge.net/EuGENia). Binaries will appear in the interim update site under version 0.8.5.200906111152 shortly.
We've recently added support for cutomizing the generated .gmftool, .gmfmap, .gmfgen and .genmodel models by means of contributing custom EOL transformations that EuGENia picks up and executes after its built-in transformations. More details about this are available here: http://epsilonlabs.wiki.sourceforge.net/EuGENia+Customization
To keep EuGENia relatively simple and not overload it with many annotations of secondary importance, I'm inclined not to add built-in support for the additional annotations requested in the wishlist and advise using the custom transformations feature discussed above instead. Any thoughts on this?
Closing this as resolved in 0.8.6. Please feel free to reopen if necessary.
Changed status to CLOSED

bug.short_desc: EglContext should be easier to overwrite

long_desc.thetext:
At the moment, a large number of attributes in EglContext are private, making it difficult to adjust them when deriving own contexts from EglContext. If these could be made protected or if protected setters could be provided (this would probably be even better), it would become much easier to define one's own contexts where needed. In particular, there should be a protected setter for the template factory so that derived contexts could easily define their own template factory. This setter should then also add the template-factory variable to the stack frame.
Also, it would be nice to expose the creation of EGLContexts on Line 246 of class EglModule as a separate factory method. This would allow sub-classes of EglModule to provide their own implementation of IEglContext.
I'll take a look at this on Monday. Thanks for reporting!
Integrated Stefan's patch.
Assigning to Dimitris for inclusion in next build.
Fixed in 0.8.9
Changed status to CLOSED

bug.short_desc: EOL/EGL 0.8.7: Unable to use keySet() method on Map

long_desc.thetext: Thanks for reporting this. I'll fix this first thing tomorrow morning and add some more tests to shield it from future regressions.

I've given it some thought and decided to revert to the old behaviour and remove the call to the removeDuplicates() method as it is not possible to identify non-modifiable collections (at least not without trying to add dummy objects - and then we would run into the problem of adding the right type of objects if the collection is of a specific type <T> only).
This implies that the caller of EolSet(Collection col) is responsible for ensuring that col doesn't contain duplicates (added this to the javadoc of the method). Any thoughts on this?

Actually, unmodifiable lists aren't the only problem with the new call of removeDuplicates in EolSet(Collection). As I said in the newsgroup, unmodifiable lists can be handled in removeDuplicates by catching and ignoring the UnsupportedOperationException that is thrown in the call to storage.clear().
For instance, when running in read-only mode inside EVL, that storage.clear() call clears the EList _and_ triggers an IllegalStateException since it's not being run inside a write transaction. Ideally, it should only throw that exception and not clear the collection, but it does both things, and that's the problem: we end up with an exception we can't recover from, as adding back the elements would cause another IllegalStateException. To avoid that exception from being thrown, we would need to check whether we're in a write transaction, but that would introduce some very ugly coupling between EolSet and EMC.
Therefore, I agree with you that it would be best to remove that call to removeDuplicates from EolSet(Collection). However, I think you should be careful with EVL's read-only mode if you add calls to removeDuplicates to any callers of EolSet(Collection). You might end up creating a regression somewhere else.

(In reply to comment #3) > Actually, unmodifiable lists aren't the only problem with the new call of > removeDuplicates in EolSet(Collection). As I said in the newsgroup, > unmodifiable lists can be handled in removeDuplicates by catching and ignoring > the UnsupportedOperationException that is thrown in the call to > storage.clear().
That's what I assumed too but it doesn't seem to hold always. For example consider the following code where clear() works but add() doesn't:
HashMap map = new HashMap(); map.put("1","2"); map.put("2","3"); Set set = map.keySet(); set.clear(); // OK set.add("foo"); // Exception
> > For instance, when running in read-only mode inside EVL, that storage.clear() > call clears the EList _and_ triggers an IllegalStateException since it's not > being run inside a write transaction. Ideally, it should only throw that > exception and not clear the collection, but it does both things, and that's the > problem: we end up with an exception we can't recover from, as adding back the > elements would cause another IllegalStateException. To avoid that exception > from being thrown, we would need to check whether we're in a write transaction, > but that would introduce some very ugly coupling between EolSet and EMC. > > Therefore, I agree with you that it would be best to remove that call to > removeDuplicates from EolSet(Collection). However, I think you should be > careful with EVL's read-only mode if you add calls to removeDuplicates to any > callers of EolSet(Collection). You might end up creating a regression somewhere > else. >
Thanks for making a note of this. It'll hopefully help avoiding such regressions in the future.
Fixed in Epsilon 0.8.8
Changed status to CLOSED

bug.short_desc: Eugenia: race condition when generating models

long_desc.thetext:
Due to the way Eugenia waits for a file to be produced, sometimes it keeps on waiting forever for a file. It's not too noticeable in a single-core or dual-core computer, but it seems to be more frequent in quad-core machines.
Normally, Eugenia starts the transformation to generate the models, refreshes the models and then waits for the file indefinitely. I think it would be safer to start generating the models and then refresh and check if the file exists repeatedly, with a slight delay between checks to avoid hogging the CPU.
Fixed in SVN r1497.
Fixed in 0.9.1

bug.short_desc: epsilon.egl task failure, when the egl explicitly generates text to target files

long_desc.thetext:
It is possible to use egl as follows, driver.egl:
[% for (i in Sequence{1..10}) { var delegate : Template; -- Pass parameters to the template delegate := TemplateFactory.load('delegate.egl'); delegate.populate('foo', i); delegate.store(i+'.txt', true); } %]
delegate.egl: [%=foo%]
That is, driver.egl triggers the execution of delegate.egl 10 times. In turn, delegate.egl prints the value of the foo parameter.
This example produces the expected txt files when driven by a standard launch configuration, but leads to a run-time error when triggered by an Ant task, such as:
<epsilon.egl src="driver.egl"/> <model ref="X"/> </epsilon.egl>
(X is referred to here, e.g., if the egl needs it, but isn't necessary.)
The exception thrown is:
[Driver.egl] Internal error: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: URI is not absolute [Driver.egl] at java.net.URI.toURL[URI.java:1080] [Driver.egl] at org.eclipse.epsilon.egl.EglModule.parse[EglModule.java:97] [Driver.egl] at org.eclipse.epsilon.egl.types.EglTemplate.<init>[EglTemplate.java:48] [Driver.egl] at org.eclipse.epsilon.egl.types.EglFileGeneratingTemplate.<init>[EglFileGeneratingTemplate.java:50] [Driver.egl] at org.eclipse.epsilon.egl.template.FileGeneratingTemplateFactory.load[FileGeneratingTemplateFactory.java:51] ...
This has been fixed and changes have been committed to the SVN. The fix will appear in 0.8.4.

bug.short_desc: Refactor EGL code to do with storing generation results

long_desc.thetext:
At the moment, this is implemented doubly: Once in EglTask and once in FileGeneratingTemplate.store. In fact, whenever I need to modify the way generated code is stored (e.g., because I am using EGL in a different environment that has its own ideas of how to manage texts), I need to effectively touch two places: EglTask and an appropriate template (including its template factory etc.).
I was wondering if it wouldn't be better to change this, so that EglModule instead of fixedly coding what to do with generated code (i.e., store it in a string attribute of the module's context) could be asked to leave this decision to a template instance? This way, there would only have to be one place where to implement storing of generated texts. Obviously, every template would have to have a store method (and we would have to come up with a suitably general parameter set for this or use a configuration pattern instead), but this would be the only place affected by any changes to storing generated code.
--
Even worse, I just noticed that there is two places in EglFileGeneratingTemplate that deal with writing to files: generate and store. Why is this not factored out?
--
Louis also noticed that worse still, EglLaunchConfigurationDelegate also contains some logic for storing the result of an EglTemplate to file.
--
Finally, while working on this, it would be nice to expose the creation of EGLContexts on Line 246 of class EglModule as a separate factory method? I'll happily provide a patch for this.
Steffen also suggested that the EpsilonBook should be updated to include information on generate.

Added dependency to #286001 to indicate that the two refactoring tasks are related (dependency is probably not the right way to express this relationship, but I couldn't find any better; feel free to adjust this).

Steffen,
I'm currently running a refactored version of EGL that might better support the extensions you envisage...
EglModule#execute now returns an EglTemplate. I've added a method to EglTemplate for retrieving the generated text: getGeneratedText(). Therefore, the old execute is equivalent to: execute().getGeneratedText().
The template returned by execute() is produced using context.getTemplateFactory(). By default, this is an instance of EglFileGeneratingTemplateFactory. Consequently, the template returned by execute() can be cast to EglFileGeneratingTemplate, and generate can be called to write the contents of the template to disk. The launch configuration delegate and ANT task now use this approach.
Therefore, EglFileGeneratingTemplate is now the only class that causes generated text to be written to disk. The write method has been changed to protected, and can be overriden by subclasses.
If enhancement #286050 (deprecating store in favour of generate) goes ahead, generate could be overriden by subclasses instead of write.
Does this sounds like a reasonable approach to you? Should I check in the source code for you to try?

Hi Louis,
Yes, this sounds nice.
The only conceptual issue I can see with this is that it effectively misuses EglFileGeneratingTemplate in some cases: Because execute doesn't call generate, an EglFileGeneratingTemplate can never be sure that its contents will really end up in a file. This may be a bit of a problem.
It would probably be cleaner not to expose the template to the caller of execute. Instead, execute could be changed to return EglResult (a new type). Additionally, the EglModule would be set up with a template properly configured (separately from the TemplateFactory in the context!) and would simply call generate on that template. This requires Template to be changed so that instead of passing a string parameter to generate, any Template has a public EglResult generate() method. Depending on what type of template it is and how it is set up, it would either return EglResult.OK to simply indicate successful generation or return an EglResult subclass that has more information on the generation result (such as, for example, the actually generated code). Then, users could decide what should happen to the generation result by passing an appropriately configured template to EglModule upon construction.
Mind you, any of these changes (both yours and my suggested alternative) are quite substantial changes to the API that will break existing applications. Thus, it is not something to rush into :-)
Best regards,
Steffen

(In reply to comment #4) > Hi Louis, > > Yes, this sounds nice. > > The only conceptual issue I can see with this is that it effectively misuses > EglFileGeneratingTemplate in some cases: Because execute doesn't call generate, > an EglFileGeneratingTemplate can never be sure that its contents will really > end up in a file. This may be a bit of a problem.
Yes, you are right. To avoid this problem, EglModule could define a generic type, <TemplateType extends EglTemplate>. execute would return an instance of the generic type. This doesn't feel like a very elegant solution, however.
> > It would probably be cleaner not to expose the template to the caller of > execute. Instead, execute could be changed to return EglResult (a new type). > Additionally, the EglModule would be set up with a template properly configured > (separately from the TemplateFactory in the context!) and would simply call > generate on that template. This requires Template to be changed so that instead > of passing a string parameter to generate, any Template has a public EglResult > generate() method. Depending on what type of template it is and how it is set > up, it would either return EglResult.OK to simply indicate successful > generation or return an EglResult subclass that has more information on the > generation result (such as, for example, the actually generated code). Then, > users could decide what should happen to the generation result by passing an > appropriately configured template to EglModule upon construction.
This is another option. Introducing an EglResult would nicely mirror a similar concept that was recently introduced for one of the other languages. I'll consider this more carefully.
> > Mind you, any of these changes (both yours and my suggested alternative) are > quite substantial changes to the API that will break existing applications. > Thus, it is not something to rush into :-)
I agree! As you suggested, we should take a look at your code and target the refactoring more closely once your work is published, of course.
Thanks again for the insight - I'm learning quite a bit from this discussion.
Best, Louis.

I've been thinking about this a bit more and am starting to wonder why we need EglModule at all :-) The responsibility of processing EGL templates obviously lies with EglTemplate (encoded in the process() method). Here, we are discussing to move the responsibility of where to put the generation result with Template as well (specifically with sub-classes of EglTemplate). Pretty much all the rest is handled by EglContext. So, what is the responsibility of EglModule in all this?
Steffen

(In reply to comment #6) > I've been thinking about this a bit more and am starting to wonder why we need > EglModule at all :-) The responsibility of processing EGL templates obviously > lies with EglTemplate (encoded in the process() method). Here, we are > discussing to move the responsibility of where to put the generation result > with Template as well (specifically with sub-classes of EglTemplate). Pretty > much all the rest is handled by EglContext. So, what is the responsibility of > EglModule in all this?
I asked myself a similar question when thinking about this. Largely, EglModule exists to provide EGL with a subclass of EolLibraryModule, which is used by the development tools. The launch configuration delegates and ANT tasks can use EglModule to parse text, URIs and files and then execute them.
Therefore, I think the responsibility of EglModule is to parse and preprocess the EGL, producing EOL which can be executed. I agree that some of this responsibility could be moved to EglTemplate. However, I think some of it must remain on EglModule to provide integration with the abstractions Epsilon uses for all development tools. Any changes that break this integration would require the EGL development tools to re-use less of the common development tools, and require more logic specific only to EGL.
I understand. But couldn't EglTemplate delegate to EolLibraryModule instead?
I'm pretty sure that EolLibraryModule is abstract, so I'd guess not.
Here's a wacky idea - EglTemplate could inherit from EolLibraryModule. I'm not sure if this would give too many responsibilities to EglTemplate though.

Whacky... :-)
It may be useful to CC Dimitrios and discuss this further at MODELS, where I'll happily give you a demo of what I've built and we can look at my code, too, to discuss what might be the best way of refactoring EGL.
Steffen

Sounds like a good idea. I won't be at MODELS, but I think that Dimitrios will be.
EGL has a fairly comprehensive (unit and end-to-end) test suite, so experimental refactoring should be possible.

To address this, the following changes have been made:
TemplateFactory is now the entry point for clients of EGL. Clients should call "load" and then "process" (or "generate") on the resulting EglTemplate.
EglContexts are no longer copied (A shared, global context and template-specific frames are used instead).
TemplateFactoryModuleAdapter can be used when a module is required, such as in the EGL development tools.
Assigning to Dimitris for integration. Thanks!
Fixed in 0.8.9
Changed status to CLOSED

bug.short_desc: importing EGL scripts into other EGL scripts doesn't work

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 171216 The archive contains the egl files, model and metamodel needed to reproduce the bug. (run driver.egl)
Overview:
One EGL file contains template operations which the other script would use. The import doesn't work.
Steps to Reproduce: 1) define a template operation in an EGL file 2) import that EGL script into another EGL script, use the operation previously defined, and run it
Actual Results:
Running fails with the error message: Method '(method name)' not found
Expected Results:
The import should work and the operation should be executed, or at least the import should be validated.

Hi Endre,
Thanks for reporting. The problem you're encountering is a regression (importing EGL files used to work in an earlier version of EGL). I'm sorry that you ran into the problem.
I've identified the root cause and am about to check-in a solution. I've also added a test to cover this case, which should help to prevent future regressions.
For our reference, the cause was the parse method of EglModule, which assumed the context field would be non-null. When EOL resolves imports, it uses a 0-arg constructor of EglModule, and context is set to null. I've moved the logic that depends on context to the execute method of EglModule, which I believe is a better home.
Cheers, Louis.
Committed to SVN. Assigning to Dimitris for build integration - thanks!
Fixed in interim version 0.8.9.201006101638
Fixed in 0.9.0.

bug.short_desc: Close the gap between the concrete syntaxes of EOL and Java

long_desc.thetext:
The syntax of EOL (and by inheritance) all other Epsilon languages could resemble the syntax of Java more closely to reduce the need for switching mental modes when jumping from Java to Epsilon and vice versa. The aim of this bug is to record ideas on possible Java-ifications. The first few follow:
Support == as well as = for comparison (non-breaking)
Support // and /**/ (in addition to -- and -**-) for comments (non-breaking)
Support "" for strings (in addition to '') and switch to `` for reserved names (breaking but not disastrous - internally we should only update the HUTN transformations)
Support for (x : col) {} in addition to for (x in col) {} (non-breaking)
Add List as an alias for Sequence (non-breaking - except if one has a List class in their metamodel)
Add "this" as an alias for "self" (non-breaking - except in case where a user-defined variable with that name exists)
Please feel free to contribute any ideas/suggestions by adding comments to this bug.
Thanks James. Could you possibly provide a patch for this?

Patch to fix the predicate rule array to include both the old style comments and the new style.
Closing as fixed. Please send any additional suggestions to the Epsilon forum.

Previously, this line worked, but after my version of Epsilon from the SVN I find that I get the following error:

I believe I am probably using the method incorrectly, as I may have unintentionally changed some of my code along the lines. However, when having a naive look in to the code, as to why this might error might be happenning I noticed that in:
org.eclipse.epsilon.egl.template.TemplateFactory
the resolveTemplate method calls UriUtil.resolve(path, templateRoot, root) -- and on inspection templateRoot and root are null. Should this be the case? Perhaps I need to call the TemplateFactory.load method differently?!

bug.short_desc: EmfModel should be able to load models not stored in the filesystem

long_desc.thetext: EmfModel#load(StringProperties, String) must be modified to use createURI instead of createFileURI. It should also be investigated what effects this has to the store() method.

A workaround and some tips provided by Steffen Zschaler in the eclipse.epsilon newsgroup:
OK, I have this bit working now. Just to document the stupid mistakes I made, in case somebody else is making them as well :-) :
* Never try to put something into a StringProperty that is not actually a String. I tried putting in a URL :-( The thing is: StringProperty will not tell you about your mistake, but will rather silently throw your input away, so that load() later on will not be able to figure out what file you are referring to... * When you convert the URL to a String, make sure of two things: o Use FileLocator.toFileURL to make sure the file is put into some accessible location o Do NOT use URL.toString() to produce the String. This will produce a String of the form "file://..." EmfModel.load cannot actually deal with this and will throw incomprehensible exceptions at you (Telling you that this is not a valid relative pathname, which is ... true). Instead, use URL.getPath() and all will be happy.
This has now been fixed in the SVN. The fix will appear in 0.8.4.
Fixed in 0.8.4

bug.short_desc: Add support for launching Eugenia from Ant files

long_desc.thetext:
The current implementation of the Epsilon Ant tasks take a src attribute with the path to a .e*l file, and do not accept URIs. Therefore, the .eol files shipped by Eugenia cannot be used unless they are unpacked from the .jar into the same project, which is rather cumbersome.
If URI support were added, platform URIs could be used to launch the Eugenia scripts and any other .e*l files that might be shipped with any other plugin.
Another option would be defining custom Ant tasks for each of the Eugenia .eol scripts. It seems to be a less flexible option, however.
Created attachment 143731 Changes to ExecutableModuleTask to enable URI support for the Epsilon Ant tasks

Created attachment 143732 (Almost) working Eclipse project with ECore model and Ant buildfile
This project contains a very simple project which defines an EMF model with Emfatic. I've included the result of converting it to ECore, just in case. It also includes a minimalistic Ant buildfile which loads this model and the GmfGen, GmfGraph and GmfTool models and tries to run the new version of the epsilon.eol task with the uri attribute set to the proper platform URI.
It should work, but somehow, I think it has problems when reading the ECore model file itself. It doesn't complain with the metamodel URIs and it does actually load the .eol file, but it reports an error saying that there was an attempt to access the name property of an undefined object. I suspect it's this line in ECore2GMF.eol which is failing (location is 10:26):
palette.title := ePackage.name + 'Palette';
There are other times when it just gives up and says that the ECore model file does not exist, though it correctly specifies the full absolute path to it in the exception message. I'm not sure what could be wrong here. :-/ Perhaps it's just my launch configuration?

Thanks for the patch Antonio. Found a slight typo in the build.xml of the example project:
<epsilon.eol uri="platform:/plugin/org.eclipse.epsilon.eugenia/transformations/ECore2GMF.el">
should be:
<epsilon.eol uri="platform:/plugin/org.eclipse.epsilon.eugenia/transformations/ECore2GMF.eol">
As mentioned on the newsgroup, the problem Antonio is encountering may be caused 285559. I've posted a partial fix to 285559 on the newsgroup. The fix is a hack and not a complete solution to 285559, so I won't add it there.
I won't check this patch into SVN just yet as I want to discuss a design decision with Dimtirios - we could potentially allow the src parameter to accept both files and URIs, distinguishing between the two at runtime. Users then wouldn't have to remember to use the src parameter for files and the uri parameter otherwise.

Nice, I didn't know Ant did that by default on String attributes :-). I just saw some code elsewhere in the Ant tasks that called replaceProperties, and assumed that it'd be necessary for the uri attribute as well.
Fixed in 0.8.7
Changed status to CLOSED

bug.short_desc: Resolution of elements with equivalents() in ETL is slow

long_desc.thetext:
Equivalent resolution seems to be a significant bottleneck in ETL. Rewriting a sample ETL transformation into plain procedural EOL seems to be reducing its execution time by almost 90%. For a sample 2MB input model the ETL transformation takes 191 sec while the EOL one only 18. The same EOL transformation transforms an input model of 60MB in under 7 mins.
There seems to be quite a bit of space for improvement in the equivalent resolution of ETL.

bug.short_desc: Add removeAt() and removeLast() to EolSequence

long_desc.thetext:
Build Identifier: 20100218-1602
It'd be useful to add explicit methods for removing elements to EolSequence. I have tried to use the remove(int) method in the underlying ArrayList, but for some reason it always ends up calling the remove(Object) method of EolCollection.
I have attached a patch which adds these two methods to EolSequence and mentions them in the Epsilon book.
Reproducible: Always
Created attachment 172666 Adds removeAt and removeLast
I meant "for removing elements to EolSequence by position" in the description. Sorry!

I've committed an implementation of the removeAt(int index) operation for instances of java.util.List (includes EolSequence) in the SVN. I'm not sure whether it's worth having a built-in removeLast() operation given that the same effect can be now produced by s.removeAt(s.size() - 1). Any thoughts on this?

I agree that removeLast() is not needed anymore. In fact, I'd say that even remove() is not needed, thanks to your removing of object wrapping altogether from Epsilon. After that, I was able to use the regular remove(int) method from List and rewrite my removeLast() calls with l.remove(l.size() - 1).
We might want to keep your new remove(int) method for consistency, though. When I read the Epsilon book, it struck me as odd that EolSequence didn't have that operation.

Thanks for your feedback! I think it makes sense to keep the removeAt(int index) method for a couple of reasons:
Sequence{1,2,3}.remove(1) -> Sequence{2,3} (it thinks 1 is an object, not an index) while Sequence{1,2,3}.removeAt(1) -> Sequence{1,3}. Also the default implementation of EolOrderedSet is a LinkedHashSet (which doesn't implement List) and we want removeAt() to be applicable on these as well. Any thoughts?

Oh, right! I forgot about the old remove-element vs remove-index ambiguity in the remove() methods in List. Yes, I agree with you in that removeAt is definitely needed. I think we can safely close this issue, then.

bug.short_desc: Cannot install Epsilon Eugenia

long_desc.thetext:
Whenever I try and install Epsilon Eugenia .8.1.1.0 from the update site, it complains as follows:
Epsilon Eugenia (Incubation) (0.8.1.1) requires plug-in "org.eclipse.gmf.graphdef (2.0.100)", or later version.
In my plugin directory, I have org.eclipse.gmf.graphdef_2.0.1.v20080207-0207.jar
When I go about -> Plug-in Details I can also see in my plugin list "GMF Graphical Definition" | version 2.0.1.v20080207-0207 | org.eclipse.gmf.graphdef
Would love to try this out on my project, but unable to install.

Thanks for reporting this. This is due to Eclipse automatically adding a minimum required version of the GMF plugins which I then forgot to remove... I've fixed this in the SVN. There are three options:
1) Download the Eclipse Modeling Distribution: http://www.eclipse.org/downloads/download.php?file=/technology/epp/downloads/release/ganymede/SR1/eclipse-modeling-ganymede-SR1-incubation-win32.zip which has the exact versions of GMF plugins required
2) Use Epsilon directly from SVN (http://www.eclipse.org/gmt/epsilon/doc/EpsilonSVN.pdf). This is probably the best option as you'll be able to pick up bug fixes immediately.
3) Wait for the next binary release (0.8.1.2) which should happen in a couple of weeks time.

I attempted to follow your directions in #2, however had issues building from subversion because of dependencies on 3.4 versions of various bundles in the
Question: is the 3.3+ description accurate, or does Epsilon/Eugenia require Ganymede to run?
Apologize if this is the wrong way to be asking this question, since I was following the fix mentioned, wanted to leave a trail for others who find this ticket.

(In reply to comment #2) > I attempted to follow your directions in #2, however had issues building from > subversion because of dependencies on 3.4 versions of various bundles in the > > Question: is the 3.3+ description accurate, or does Epsilon/Eugenia require > Ganymede to run?
There is nothing in the code that requires 3.4 - actually until recently we were working on 3.3 ourselves. The problem is that for plugins created in 3.4, Eclipse is adding a minimum required version which it sets to the current version it finds at the time. Feel free to remove the required version numbers in the problematic MANIFEST.MF files. Later on today I'll check out the code using 3.3 and and try to eliminate them for good.
> > Apologize if this is the wrong way to be asking this question, since I was > following the fix mentioned, wanted to leave a trail for others who find this > ticket. >
No worries. Posts in newsgroups are generally far more visible but the bugzilla is also good when it comes to defects like this one.

Once again, followed instructions in #2 for subversion. There was one file that had to do with ui draw2d which was not used for anything, that I commented out. I then painstakingly changed all the references to version numbers that didn't exist in 3.3 to 3.3 compatible versions in the manifest as well as feature.xml files.
Successfully built, created a local update site, and was able to install in 3.3!
This has now been fixed in the SVN. The change will appear in the upcoming 0.8.2 binaries.
Fixed in 0.8.2
Changed status to CLOSED

bug.short_desc: Calling static methods natively

long_desc.thetext:
Calling static methods seems like a useful feature that should be supported natively by Epsilon.
From newsgroup:
Hi Darren,
Since Pattern doesn't provide an accessible constructor - only the static "compile" method, you should create your own tool that wraps Pattern (using Java) and then call it from Epsilon.
Having said this, calling static methods seems like a useful feature that should be supported natively by Epsilon. Would you mind opening an enhancement request in the bugzilla for this?
Cheers, Dimitris
Darren Clowes wrote:
Hi All,
I'm trying to execute some regular expression searches in a transformation. The Java I need to execute uses the Java.utils.regex.Pattern and Java.utils.regex.Matcher. Dimtitris kindly pointed me to the Epsilon Tools documentation and I can follow the JFrame example. However from what I can tell there is no default constructor for Pattern, which is what I believe to be causing me the problems.
Pattern is typically called in Java by: Pattern p = Pattern.compile('regex Srring');
I have tried: # var pattern : new Native('java.util.regex.Pattern') := pattern.compile('Section ((\\d)[(\\.\\d)]*)'); # var pattern : new Native('java.util.regex.Pattern') := Pattern.compile('Section ((\\d)[(\\.\\d)]*)'); # var pattern : new Native('java.util.regex.Pattern') := java.util.regex.Pattern.compile('Section ((\\d)[(\\.\\d)]*)'); # var pattern : new Native('java.util.regex.Pattern');
All of which result in an EXCEPTION: Internal error: java.lang.InstantiationException: java.util.regex.Pattern
Has anyone any suggestions to try.
Many thanks,
Darren

bug.short_desc: [EGL] Is @template now redundant?

long_desc.thetext:
Given that operations now have access to the out variable (see 347016) and hence can use dynamic output sections, it's not clear whether we need the @template operation as well.
Either way, we need to update the Epsilon documentation as there is a less obvious distinction between annotated and unannotated operations now.

Thinking about this, "standard" (unannotated) operations and @template operations are indeed different, and both seem to have their own use cases. I will update the book to reflect this, and will include the example below.
Consider the following code. @template operations return a string that can be postprocessed before being emitted (e.g. the call to firstToLowerCase below). Standard operations, by contrast, return no useful value and instead emit text as soon as they generate it.
[* The following returns no value, and immediately outputs "1" *] [% "Foo".unannotated(); %] [* The following returns a String, and hence permits postprocessing *] [%="Foo".annotated()%] [%="Foo".annotated().firstToLowerCase()%]
[% operation Any unannotated() {%] [%=self%] (from standard operation) [% } %] [% @template operation Any annotated() {%] [%=self%] (from template operation) [% } %]

This bug now relates only to the Epsilon Book.
I've added a section on "user-defined operations in EGL" to the Epsilon Book, and committed it to SVN.

bug.short_desc: [EOL] Prevent foreach from throwing concurrent modification exceptions

long_desc.thetext:
Just a few comments:
on 1) There's actually no need to do a deep clone. All that needs to be cloned is the actual collection structure, there is no problem if it references the same elements. In fact, you would probably want it to, as otherwise you would end up with two copies of each model element and delete would probably delete the wrong one :-) So, a better way to code this maybe for (BElemType a : new Collection(b)) { ... }
on 2) The problem is not really the use of for or while. The problem is in using an iterator and modifying the collection it iterates over.
on 3) This looks neat. Of course, there already is collection.excluding :-)
Steffen

(In reply to comment #2) > 3) I think allowing the delete keyword in the body of forAll might be better > than a new method on Collection: I agree that there may be confusion between a > new method Collection#delete and Collection#excluding (there's also > Collection#remove, Collection#exlcudingAll, Collection#removeAll)
Hang on, if there already is a Collection#remove, shouldn't that be enough? Or is this currently not available to EOL users?
On a related note, I'm not sure allowing delete inside forAll is such a good idea: forAll is meant to check a predicate over a collection (at least I assume that's true for EOL as well) and not modify the collection. So allowing delete would mean quite a substantial change to forAll's semantics.
Steffen

(In reply to comment #3) > (In reply to comment #2) > > 3) I think allowing the delete keyword in the body of forAll might be better > > than a new method on Collection: I agree that there may be confusion between a > > new method Collection#delete and Collection#excluding (there's also > > Collection#remove, Collection#exlcudingAll, Collection#removeAll) > > Hang on, if there already is a Collection#remove, shouldn't that be enough? Or > is this currently not available to EOL users?
Delete is somewhat different to Collection#remove. Delete removes the model element from the model. (So, in EMF, delete will remove the model element from the underlying EResource). Collection#remove doesn't remove the model element from the resource, and is useful for moving elements from one collection to another.
Incidentally, attempting to save a model after calling Collection#remove can fail (e.g. dangling hrefs in EMF), but saving a model after calling delete won't cause these types of error.
> > On a related note, I'm not sure allowing delete inside forAll is such a good > idea: forAll is meant to check a predicate over a collection (at least I assume > that's true for EOL as well) and not modify the collection. So allowing delete > would mean quite a substantial change to forAll's semantics.
I'm not sure if it's good practice, but I use EOL's Collection#forAll to inline small loops. Often I disregard the return value. For example:
for (e in myCollection) { e.name.println(); }
becomes
myCollection.forAll(e|e.name.println());

One further point to consider... if we go for option (1), a shallow copy of the collection, I *think* we may need to do some extra work to ensure that the properties of the collection are preserved. For example, when iterating over an OrderedSet, we may need to ensure that the clone is also an OrderedSet, and not some other type of collection that doesn't preserve ordering and uniqueness.

Really, you would only need to preserve properties that would be exhibited through the iterator (mainly ordering, I guess). Any modifications would go to the original collection anyway.
Steffen

Dimitris and I have discussed this offline, and we've decided to add some documentation to cover this behaviour, and not to change anything else. We haven't decided on a good solution yet, but will leave the bug open for further discussion.
In short, the main concern with the proposed solutions are that they may introduce unexpected or (hard to understand) results in future passes over a loop.
Also, allowing a delete statement in the body of forAll wouldn't avoid the problem, as forAll is implemented as a Java for loop.
Fixed in 0.9.0.

bug.short_desc: ClassCastException when assigning enum literal to attribute

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 144437 Patch which apparently resolves the issue
Build ID: 20090619-0625
Steps To Reproduce: I'm getting ClassCastExceptions when I try to assign to the viewMethod and editMethod attributes of GmfMap!FeatureLabelMapping. Here's a simplified example which shows the problem:
var lm := new GmfMap!FeatureLabelMapping; var y := GmfMap!LabelTextAccessMethod#PRINTF; y.println(); lm.viewMethod := y; -- <- fails
It produces the following output:
EEnumLiteral [name=PRINTF, value=3, instance=PRINTF, literal=PRINTF, ] Internal error: java.lang.ClassCastException: org.eclipse.emf.ecore.impl.EEnumLiteralImpl at org.eclipse.gmf.mappings.impl.FeatureLabelMappingImpl.eSet[FeatureLabelMappingImpl.java:367] at org.eclipse.emf.ecore.impl.BasicEObjectImpl.eSet[BasicEObjectImpl.java:1073] at org.eclipse.epsilon.emc.emf.EmfPropertySetter.invoke[EmfPropertySetter.java:53] at org.eclipse.epsilon.eol.execute.AssignExecutor.execute[AssignExecutor.java:55] at org.eclipse.epsilon.eol.execute.ExecutorFactory.executeAST[ExecutorFactory.java:184] at org.eclipse.epsilon.eol.execute.StatementBlockExecutor.execute[StatementBlockExecutor.java:33] at org.eclipse.epsilon.eol.execute.ExecutorFactory.executeAST[ExecutorFactory.java:184] at org.eclipse.epsilon.eol.EolModule.execute[EolModule.java:57] at org.eclipse.epsilon.eol.dt.launching.EolLaunchConfigurationDelegate.launch[EolLaunchConfigurationDelegate.java:96] at org.eclipse.debug.internal.core.LaunchConfiguration.launch[LaunchConfiguration.java:853] at org.eclipse.debug.internal.core.LaunchConfiguration.launch[LaunchConfiguration.java:703] at org.eclipse.debug.internal.ui.DebugUIPlugin.buildAndLaunch[DebugUIPlugin.java:866] at org.eclipse.debug.internal.ui.DebugUIPlugin$8.run[DebugUIPlugin.java:1069] at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run[Worker.java:55] (/home/antonio/.../TestEnumLiteralFromEnumClass/test.eol@5:14)
More information: I haven't had this sort of problem with my own models. I suspect these differences have to do with the slightly different way those enumerations are declared in the GMF code. For instance, here's the header for one of my enumerations:
public final class NodeSide extends AbstractEnumerator ...
AbstractEnumerator is part of EMF:
public abstract class AbstractEnumerator implements Enumerator, Serializable ...
And here's what the LabelTextAccessMethod enumeration uses:
public enum LabelTextAccessMethod implements Enumerator ...
I've managed to produce a workaround for the problem, which extracts the enumeration instance from the EEnumLiteralImpl wrapper when the enumeration literal is evaluated. With this patch, it seems to work, but I'm not sure if that's the right approach. I've also attached a sample project with the EOL script above.
Created attachment 144438 Test project which reproduces the problem
I've applied your patch and updated EuGENia not to use .instance . The change will appear in 0.8.7. Many thanks for your help with this!
Fixed in 0.8.7

bug.short_desc: [EUnit] Arguments of assert* (except assertError) are evaluated twice

long_desc.thetext:
I have found out that, apparently, every argument for an assert* operation (such as assertTrue) is evaluated twice. This is a performance problem, and may produce incorrect results if any of the repeatedly evaluated expressions has side effects.
I have attached an EOL script which reproduces the problem on Epsilon SVN (r1520 and beyond, as it depends on the fix for bug #349207). Both assertions in this script should pass. However, the second assertion fails:
start with seq1 first time: setting to 1 end with seq1 start with seq2 first time: setting to 1 incremented to 2 Expected 1, but got 2 instead (/home/antonio/Documentos/sodmt/workspace-metamodels/EOLScratchpad/testDoubleEvaluation.eol@12:0)
After looking at the code, it seems to be caused by the way method lookups are performed in PointExecutor#execute:
- non-overrdable operations (assertError seems to be the only one) are run - parameters are evaluated - find and run user-defined operation if applicable - find and run method contributor if applicable - overridable operations (such as assertEquals or assertTrue)
Since those overridable operations evaluate the parameters once more, every parameter will be evaluated twice.
I'm not quite sure about what would be the best way to fix this. Some operations (such as select or aggregate) do need specific code to parse their internal ASTs, but most AbstractSimpleOperations do not. We could add a special case for overridable AbstractSimpleOperations, but that sounds like a hack and not like a general solution.
Created attachment 197900 EOL script which reproduces the problem (requires SVN r1520 or later)

Created attachment 197902 Patch which fixes the issue, assuming all built-in operations are not overridable
For the time being, I'm working around the issue by assuming none of these operations can be overridden. Here is the patch I'm using.

We fixed this on SVN on our last meeting. Since then, I have moved the EUnit assertions to three new operation contributors:
- a basic contributor with all assertions that are simple and do not require additional dependencies (in eol.engine).
- an extra contributor with assertions that are more complex and/or require additional dependencies (in eunit.engine).
- a contributor which is added from the EUnit Ant task, as the contributed operations require a reference to the Ant Project instance.
Fixed in 0.9.1

bug.short_desc: CollectionAnnotator must use WeakHashMap

long_desc.thetext: CollectionAnnotator must use WeakHashMap instead of HashMap<WeakReference, Object> to simplify interface and reduce memory usage.
Fixed in the SVN

It's not so simple, I'm afraid. After debugging for two hours the test that started failing since this morning, I've found this paragraph in the WeakHashMap javadoc:
"This class is intended primarily for use with key objects whose equals methods test for object identity using the == operator. Once such a key is discarded it can never be recreated, so it is impossible to do a lookup of that key in a WeakHashMap at some later time and be surprised that its entry has been removed. This class will work perfectly well with key objects whose equals methods are not based upon object identity, such as String instances. With such recreatable key objects, however, the automatic removal of WeakHashMap entries whose keys have been discarded may prove to be confusing."
The problem is that ArrayList (e.g. EolSequence) uses AbstractList's equals() method, which is based on content. For this reason, we will lose whatever annotations we had when we add an element to a collection.
We will probably need to wrap the objects in a type whose equals() method uses object identity, I'm afraid. I'll try this and report back in a while.

I'm thinking of several options:
- using a wrapper doesn't really work, as it'd be freed automatically (nobody holds a strong reference to the wrapper)
- redefining equals() in Eol* can break existing code
We could define our own equivalent of WeakHashMap which ignores the equals() method of the keys, but that sounds pretty difficult :-/.
I'll keep on looking.

There are alternative maps which do have the desired semantics, according to this Stack Exchange article:
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1709965/java-implementation-of-notification-provider-vs-hashcode-driven-map
In particular, Apache Commons has the ReferenceIdentityMap:
http://commons.apache.org/collections/api-release/org/apache/commons/collections/map/ReferenceIdentityMap.html
And Google Collections has its MapMaker:
http://google-collections.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/javadoc/index.html?com/google/common/collect/MapMaker.html
Both are under the Apache License 2.0. The Apache Commons class seems to be the easiest to use. I think there would be no legal issues if we included the Apache Commons Collections .jar as a dependency. Galileo has a bunch of Apache License third-party dependencies itself:
http://www.eclipse.org/eclipse/development/project-log-files/eclipse_project_3_5_log.html
What do you think?

The issue seems to have been resolved with the ReferenceIdentityMap from Apache Commons. Here is a sequence of patches: the first one adds Apache Commons as a dependency, and the next one changes CollectionAnnotator to use ReferenceIdentityMap.
The first patch may probably not apply correctly if you're not using Git: just create a project from the latest JAR and add it to the dependencies and the eol.engine projects:
http://mirror.fubra.com/ftp.apache.org//commons/collections/binaries/commons-collections-3.2.1-bin.tar.gz
The second patch should apply cleanly, though.
Fixed in 0.9.1

bug.short_desc: [EOL] Collection#concat/0 (was Collection#join)

long_desc.thetext:
I've been using a Collection#join method for a lot of EGL templates, and I think it's time to promote it to a built-in method in EOL:
var s = Sequence{'foo','bar','baz'}
s.join() -> 'foobarbaz' s.join('-') -> 'foo-bar-baz'
Collection#join(pattern) is the inverse of String#split(pattern)

I've added join to CollectionOperationContributor, added some tests to CollectionTests and updated the Epsilon book.
Assigning to Dimitris for build integration; thanks!

In fact, there is already a concat operator that is equivalent to join/1.
I've removed join/0 and join/1 and added concat/0.

Fixed in 0.9.1

bug.short_desc: Add support for additional EMF resource types

long_desc.thetext: Up to version 0.8.5.200904301737, all EMF models are being loaded using IDXMIResource. This is too restrictive as it doesn't allow Epsilon to operate on models backed by other resource types (e.g. XML models that conform to an Ecore generated from an XSD).

A fix has been committed to the SVN that changes the behaviour of the EMF driver so that it respects registered resource types. For example, when loading a .gmfmap model, an org.eclipse.gmf.internal.map.util.GMFMapResource is now created instead of an IDXMIResource.
@Louis: I can't seem to be able to run the tests in my machine cause I'm getting the following error message:
Error occurred during initialization of VM Could not reserve enough space for object heap
Could you please run the tests and verify that I haven't broken anything (again)?
This change should have no side-effects except changing the default behaviour of XML/XMI resources from UUID to non-UUID element IDs.

I've updated from SVN and run EpsilonTestSuite - all the tests are still passing with this change.
WRT the object heap problem, I use the following VM arguments for the EpsilonTestSuite configuration (on a machine with 4GB RAM): -Xms1024m -Xmx1024m -XX:PermSize=512m -XX:MaxPermSize=512m
PS - I removed a debug statement from EmfModel, which was causing the tests to run less quickly.
Oops.. I forgot about that. Thanks for the tip and for running the tests. I'll roll out a new version in the interim update site now and the fix will appear in 0.8.6
